reviewText:
Luftrausers isn't a dogfighting game. Yes, you're in a plane and you're shooting down planes (and boats and blimps), but what it really is frenetic aerial bullet hell chaos. But what makes Luftrausers so good, besides the action and stylized graphics, are the controls. Your plane is insanely maneuverable, able to turn on a dime, reach top speed in a moment. That level of control makes a difference.

It's one thing to weave between some bullets and return fire. It's another to swoop into a dive, deftly plummet through a hail storm of bullets, take out a projectile-spewing battleship, and pull up so close that the water's surface is flared up by your thrusters.

It's one thing to shoot down some planes. It's another to maneuver your enemies into a tight cluster, cut your thrusters, and shoot the planes pursuing you while your momentum carries you in the other direction. (And it helps that just activating your thrusters is so satisfying, thanks to the awesome fwhoosh sound effect)

It's fast, it's hard as hell, it's addictive. The music is great. The visuals are simple, yet suit the game perfectly, displaying all the information you need to know without cluttering the onscreen spectacle. Each new part you unlock feels different, a new tool to master, Luftrausers isn't the most complex game, but it's certainly one of the most addictive and satisfying I've played in a while. I'd say it's up there with One Finger Death Punch, in terms of a simple experience that's laser focused on delivering finely tuned fun gameplay. It's the kind of game where I'm instantly restarting upon defeat, to improve my skills, complete missions, unlock new parts.

reviewText:
A fallacious argument regarding arcade games is that they're designed solely to take your money. If anything, arcade games make you value your money. Think about it, your life is represented by a mere quarter. With practice that quarter could take you anywhere you want to go. For most of us nowadays, the only exposure to arcade games is through the occasional port or MAME. We've lost sight of how much a quarter is worth.

What a lot of arcade-style games get wrong is that they have too much content. They have a lot of fluff like epic intros, backstories, dozens of stages, freakin' level-ups. I don't play an arcade game for all that filth, I want a good challenge, I want the action to start seconds after I begin. Luftrausers understands what makes an arcade game work, and it's fantastic.

So uh...there's a war or something, you're a pilot, and oh who cares? You're either very skilled or exceptionally lucky to survive five minutes of this hell. The goal is to fly around, shoot down enemy fighters, destroy their boats, wreck their aces, sink their battleships, obliterate their subs, and probably wipe out their airships. One element of a good arcade game is that you can grasp its mechanics and controls in seconds. The enemy numbers are overwhelming but dodging and returning fire is seamless and impeccably designed. Your goals are simply to improve hi-score, complete various missions, and unlock parts.

Whoa back up, unlock parts? What is this? It's actually a very clever system. The parts in this game aren't just +1 to armor or +3 to fire-power. They change up the player's entire style and strategy. There are a multitude of weapon, body, and engine combinations. Finding the one that suits you is all part of the fun. For example, having a propellor equipped allows the player's ship to not take damage underwater. When the heat becomes a little too much, it's possible to duck into the sea for a quick breather. Couple this with the laser cannon and enemies can be destroyed while firing from underwater. Every combination leads to various changes in how every game is played, and with each attempt lasting minutes at the most, there's a lot of ideas to play around with.

What makes this such a smartly-designed game is that it does a lot with very little. There are maybe 7 or 8 enemy-types in the entire game, but they're used just right to make every game feel fresh. Changing the parts of your ship or focusing on different objectives can also make every attempt feel different from the last. I've gotten more than a couple hours out of this tiny game precisely because it knows what works and runs with it.

Definitely pick up Luftrausers if you haven't already. If you're the bundle-purchasing type it has to be in your library already. If not...well...oops? Grab it during the next sale, or buy it right now. Just play this game next chance you get, it's definitely worth it.

reviewText:
LUFTRAUSERS is a bullet hell airplane based game, being released on PC, PS3 and Vita in early 2014.

Game play is quite simple, you are in control of a airplane and you have to take on hundreds and hundreds of other enemy fighters coming at you from all angles. This game allows your plane to fly in all 360 degrees. Your main weapon will shoot from the front of your plane, you also have to take into consideration things like gravity, stalling and drifting whilst dodging all of the oncoming enemies.  Initially the controls seem very hard to get a grasp of, but once you work out how the plane flies and how you are supposed to control it, it becomes almost second nature. I would say it took me at least an hour to get to grips with the controls.

Graphically, the game has a very minimalist look to it. Whilst there is little detail gone into the planes and their silhouettes, you still feel like you are actually there in the skies shooting the planes down yourself.  They could of quite easily made this look like a many of the other flight games on Steam, I think its the graphics and art style that most people will remember this game for.

There isn't really any story or plot to follow in LUFTRAUSERS. I also didn't really want one too; it's perfectly fine for a game not to have a plot I think. After all, your character can nose dive your plane into an enemy battleship, reap the rewards from it and move onto the next character without batting an eyelid.

The game also has a kind of rogue-like feel to it, after each level, you are able to customize your plane with different weapons and armor, and you keep all of the updates even after you die, along with any levels and points you have earned. Eventually you'll get more powerful and be able to simply overpower some stages purely because your plane will be kitted up so much.

LUFTRAUSERS is a very hard game. I have died countless times, you just need to get used to it - there is no way around it. But if you preserver through, you'll soon be able to break through that wall you have been pounding your head on for an hour and beat the challenges that are set at the start of each level.  In order for me to reach the end"

reviewText:
This game starts very fun with polished controls and a great visual style. I enjoyed it for the first hour, maybe two hours, but in the end the sudden drop off of entertainment and other drawbacks forced me to not recommend this game.

The game lacks good progression/unlockable balance. There is overall goals and levels but also each item comes with different unlockable goals. This is the only reason you would bother using most options beyond a one time try to see what they are". Basically the system forces you to use items you don't prefer. But if like most people you find a weapon/armor/boost combo you prefer and play it often you run the risk of grinding your overall score up which is connected to your level progression... Which changes the spawn rates of enemies. And that's where the balance is quickly lost. There's one "right" way to progress and even if you did it and methodically unlocked each upgrade's goals as you got them without wasted plays I still doubt it would stay balanced. And this isn't a complaint about difficulty!

I like a challenge and this game gives it when you get a lot of enemies at once. But the spawning balance just ruins a reasonable chance at a goal and makes it a lottery. Luck isn't a challenge
date:
it is just luck. Skill goes out the window. And you do get to the point where you tap out. The goals you have left indeed become purely luck based or based on enemy spawns that rarely if ever cooperate. The game goes from a steady two hours of fun challenge of unlocks and goals... To a test of  your willpower to grind and grind with items you don't like until you literally get lucky and win the lottery.

Which I guess points out one last flaw. Without the goals this game loses all of it's appeal. With runs so short it isn't rewarding in any way to just play for "fun" without a goal. An average run is under a minute. This makes playing it like an arcade game just going for a high score both pointless and repetitive.

Had some fun playing it. It was a challenge at times and the gameplay felt tight. It was a pleasure to look at stylistically too. But then the fun ended. Completely. Beyond being a throw in game in a bundle I can't recommend it. And it isn't a reason to get a bundle either. The price is way out of balance with what you actually get; A way out of balance short game."

reviewText:
Luftrausers is a small, arcade-style game that packs a punch... if that's the sort of thing you're into.

The thing with Luftrausers is, not everyone's going to like it. I don't want to convince you that it's good, I want to tell you about it and let you make that decision. There is no story mode. There are no levels. It's one area, you fly around, you shoot as many things as you can, you die, repeat.

First off, let's talk about that. It's a game about flying around in an advanced German fighter plane machine thing and shooting up the enemies. Various airborne and seaborne war vehicles will try to shoot you down. And, sooner or later, they will succeed.

Probably sooner.

Your controls are a surprising part of what makes the game fun. You have your propulsion, which will move you forward. You also have right and left, which will turn you. Gravity is a thing here, it's not your typical bullet hell. But gravity is what allows you to perform cool aerial maneuvers. Fly directly up, stall your craft, then fall down past your enemies and blast upward at them. Laying back into the propulsion at the last minute to fly off to the side and dodge a battleship's bullets, of course.

Now, there are two things which add replayability, here. First, is the diversity in equipment. You begin the game with a basic machine gun, basic aircraft body, and basic propulsion system. As you go, you unlock four more of each, all of which completely change how your craft performs and operates. One type of propulsion lets you go underwater without taking damage. One weapon is a continuous laser beam which hinders your turn speed when in use. One body is a nuke which destroys almost anything around when you die. Which, actually, that last one's a ton more useful than it sounds.

Which brings me to the other thing. Missions. Each piece of equipment has a series of missions attached to it. Complete one, unlock the next. These are things like destroying so many of something, or blowing something up with a full combo going. Some are a little more outside the box, but there you go. Once you complete all of the normal missions, one final mission unlocks, which must be completed in SFMT mode, which is, for lack of a better label, hard mode. This unlocks the first time you destroy a blimp. And good luck with that. You're going to need it. And you're going to need it even more when you actually start SFMT mode.

Completing missions nets you skulls, and as you unlock enough or level up, you unlock new equipment. Once all of the equipment is unlocked, you unlock palettes. The basic palette is a sort of retro-beige affair. My favorite was the first one I unlocked, titled Videodreaming"
date: which is sort of indigo and pink
recommended: and honestly looks really cool. Most of the others I unlocked were eyesores
hoursPlayed: so there's a thing to be aware of.\n\nThat's honestly about all there is to it. You swoop and loop and blow stuff up and complete challenges and unlock things. I wouldn't expect to get TONS of time out of Luftrausers. But a few hours would be natural. If that all sounds appealing
voteText: then check it out."

reviewText:
LUFTRAUSERS is a challenging arcade shooter that makes you fight to beat your high score. There's no deep story or hero with a traumatic past here. Just you gunning down countless waves of scum who deny you the right to the skies.

Here's a video giving you my first impressions of the game. Although given how short it is, you may be able to consider it a review.

http://youtu.be/l1Fuvydgcp4

For those of you who want a short and dirty summary, I'll break it down for you with pros and cons.

+ Challenging gameplay. There isn't a point where you'll ever be bored with how easy something is.
+ Great replayability. No game will ever play the same, especially when you throw in all the different plane parts into the mix.
+ Lots of different playstyles. You can fly everything from a plane that spearheads through destroyers to a meaty clunker that fires a laser and poops bullets.
+ Smooth, responsive gameplay. Nothing feels clunky and everything responds when you do it.
+ Every shade of yellow you can find is here. Bask in its yellow glory! (Though you can change the scheme when you level up, but why?)

- Extremely short. After playing 3 hours, I've practically done everything in the game.
- Some of the weapons just aren't as good as others in my opinion. The homing missiles seem to have a lot of trouble hitting their target, even massive destroyers that barely move. Limiting you to 4 at a time makes it even more frustrating when they don't hit what they're supposed to. The cannon is similar, as it only allows one shot at a time, and if you miss, you have a lot of downtime between shots. And in a game as fast-paced as this, missing happens often.
- Sometimes enemies just don't spawn and come after you. It makes it hard to bump up combos and get more points, allowing the more interesting enemies trying to gun you down.
- Sometimes the game can be cheap and send 3 destroyers at you at a time with a few ace pilots to boot. At that point, you're just not gonna live with the amount of things on screen.


All in all, I recommend you pick this game up when you want an excellent time waster. Even when it goes up to 10 dollars, it'll still be worth it. But if you don't like the fact that it is so short, feel free to wait until it goes on sale. You won't be disappointed either way.

reviewText:
I strongly recommend trying the original flash game before buying: http://www.vlambeer.com/?p=496

This sequel essentially extrapolates the original's gameplay into various goals while existing in a singular world.
Ship components are unlocked after completing these goals. The patterns of enemies remain roughly the same, with the exception of boss-esque appearances.

The core gameplay is phenomenal, but the lack of variety comes as huge a disappointment. What about a mission-based system, or campaign? Different missions with combinations of the enemies. One level could be entirely naval-based, another strictly dogfighting ... the list goes on.

To conclude, if you enjoy the original flash demo, go for it, but don't expect much more than the challenges and ship mods.

reviewText:
Well first off let me say that the experience of playing Luftrausers cannot be described nor felt via screenshots.. Videos might give you some idea.   I used to play the prototype flash game for hours and that was without any upgrades or any of the new stuff.  The minimal graphics are amazingly detailed, from debres and shrapnel flying from your plane and enemies, to smoke and bullets and even water dripping off after you splash down.

The controls are very solid, and relay the power and abilities of the chosen engine well.  High tech engines feel snappy and powerful and the odd-job (bullet) engines feel sluggish and less responsive.  Once you learn to steer well, the game really opens up and is amazingly entertaining.

Well that is until a jet screams onto your screen and smashes you into tiny pixels.

I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys shooters, bullet hell, action rogue-lites.

And since a friend of a friend saw on some forum that this is a free flash game, let me set the record straight.  It began life as a ULTRA simple version of the current game a long time ago. And while the prototype is still available, the full version adds missions, and level / upgrade system and many more enemies and is totally worth the few bucks.  Although the prototype will give you a basic feel of how the game plays (keyboard and mouse only I believe) the full version offers controller support.

And I mean, who doesn't want to support some of the most awesome indie devs around?

9/10 Anyday.

reviewText:
This is a brilliant little arcade style game. Incidentaly I picked this up in a Humble Bundle, but already before I start this review I'd say that it is definitly worth full price!
Luftrausers is an oldschool arcade style game, with focus on racking up as many points as possible, while sustaining a multiplier. To do this you gun down hundreds of planes, ships, and various modifications and bosstypes of these.
The game does however feature some progression, in that you will be offered various jobs to complete, and by doing that you will progressively unlock parts to your plane, which comes with more jobs to do. There is also colourschemes to unlock,  since the artstyle is uses a simple 4-5 colour pallette.
The unlockable parts gives a whole lot of vararity, and there's a bunch of different playstyles, depending on how you combine your plane. Personally I'm a big fan of the laser+melee body+booster engine combo.
Gameplay continues to be fun, and even after you have completed all jobs and unlocked all parts, there is more to do, a hardcore mode will unlock, which is really hardcore. You will basically die within seconds, and this mode comes with additional jobs to do.
Luftrausers is ultmatively a bunch of fun, with flying mechanics that feel really awesome, and gamplay that keeps on giving. It does however run in some wierd aspect ratio (most likely 4:3) and there is no way to make it wide screen as far as I have seen, but this doesn't really detract from the game in any way.

I would definitly reccomend this game if you are into arcade style games with scores and multipliers. Or if you just want to waste some time shooting thing out of a brown sky.
Go get it!

reviewText: Looks a bit like Sopwith, controls a bit like Asteroids with gravity.  It feels good to fly and shoot in this, and in general the feedback for your actions and status is good.  The choice to make this game look like military profile diagrams fighting in a newsreel makes it easy to see what's going on, but they've managed to put nice details in like the turbulence of your plane kicking up spray off the ocean.  All the parts you can customise your plane with are distinct and force different play styles.\n\nIt's a solid foundation for a good game, but the scoring and enemy spawning system is screwed up and destroys any appeal to seeking high scores.  Luck will determine if you can carry a full score multiplier (and it's a big multiplier) because sometimes small planes and boats don't spawn often enough.  Sometimes four or five big, deadly planes will spawn at once and spell doom for all but a few specific plane part combos.  The game derives its longevity instead through hiding the different plane parts behind missions, many of which only ask you be persistent than skillfull (accumulate X points over however many tries it takes).  You're going to notice the game's problems well before you get the last part.

reviewText:
This is a bit of a cautious recommendation. I will say that the game is pretty fun on its own, with an interesting theme going on. It's basically a bullet-hell game (with, I'd argue, some rogue-like elements). Point of the game is to las as long as you can over dangerous waters, fighting bots, planes and Zeppelins. I will say that the gameplay is really solid and interesting; you'll be flying all over the place while shooting, and can even cut off your engines to pull off maneuvers to get the edge on your enemies. It's a good arcade experience that you should have some fun with, and that's added with the unlocks that you get from completing challenges. The unlocks include new bodies of the plane, as well as weapons, wings, and engines. These pieces have their own stats, but also have a few interesting quirks, an example being an engine that shoots bullets. With the customization, it's a good bit of fun.

So why is it cautious, you ask? Well, what cuts this game off from being great is its price at ten dollars which, in my opinion, is very overpriced. While the action is hectic, you'll be fighting in the same area and with the same enemies over and over and over again. On top of that, while the unlocks are great fun, there are too few to unlock (I got all of them at the 1.5 mark). It really isn't that hard to get all of the items in this game. Once you unlock all of your parts and essentially the hard mode, the only thing to strive for afterwards is completing challenges (which kind of loses its luster once everything is unlocked). Don't get me wrong, it's a fun game, but I'd highly recommend you buy it one it's on sale. Got my copy on Chronogg for a dollar fifty, which I think is a much more fair price.

All in all, a fun game, but doesn't offer enough for its asking price.
voteText: 13 of 16 people (81%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Look at the video for Luftrausers, where you can have a bunch of fighters chasing your plane, cut the engines in mid air, spin around, strafe them, and zoom off in the opposite direction. Yes, Luftrausers does let you be a crazy plane badass. Sadly, that's about the only good point.

The whole thing feels like an Iphone game, but brings almost enough excitement that it could qualify as a real game. Runs are short. You'll die within 5 minutes, easily. The score system is arbitrary and meaningless for the very same reason I cannot recommend the game.

Beyond the fighters, every other enemy simply takes too much damage to kill. By the game you have made the five or so passes needed to kill a battleship, three more have spawned, and they will ALL be training their sights on you while you try to kill the others. And you have boats, planes, subs, and jets to deal with while you're trying to ice these. The score system relies on a chaining mechanic and every single tough enemy takes more damage to kill than it takes your chain to drop, so you can only hope to play for score by hoping the RNG throws you a bunch of suicidal popcorn fighters and jets. The big bad blimp boss of the game is a total pushover unless you have to fight it while two dozen battleships also try to nail you from below but he may as well take twice as much sustained fire as you have put out since the game started to get him to show up and fight. The enemy variety is just tedious and sucks the fun out of the game beyond that initial rush where you duplicate the preview video's cool tricks.

Like an Iphone game, you can do three objectives each time to unlock parts to customize your plane and they're really the actual goal of the game as they block all the unlocks and provide you the only sort of direction you get beyond getting shot at. The plane parts are roughly 25% cool, 75% stupid, and share the same loose, uninspiring design as the basic game. Some change core mechanics in fundamental ways but they are not enough to save the game.

$10 for a tight arcade experience would be a no brainer but Luftrausers just does not have that spark that makes an arcade game fun. You won't come back to it months later to revisit the fond memories. It burns out too quick and does not leave much beyond the flash... Which is a shame as a lot of love and care went into the glitz and the flash and the style of it but a little more should have went into tightening the gameplay.

reviewText:
8/10
Overview: Shoot Em Up

The Good:

+ Simple, clean art style that fits the style of the game

+ There is only one ship that you can customize between 3 body parts- Weapons, body and engine. There are 5-6 parts in each category depending on how many you unlock, giving you well over 100 different combinations. Each body part is unique and provides its own sets of strengths and weaknesses depending on your play style.

+ Every body part you choose has 5 bonus objectives for you to complete giving you something to play for other than a high score. For example certain objectives may include 'kill 5 planes in one play session', 'destroy a battleship', 'kill a ship at max combo etc'.

+ The game has the one more time' feeling. The game can be very addicting as you try to get new high scores or complete objectives

+Two difficulty modes to test your skills
date:
normal and hard

+Solid Soundtrack

The Average:

The UI leaves something to be desired
recommended: it could have been a lot easier to navigate menu screens. Given the context of the game there really is no reason to have a UI that isn't simple and easy to navigate.\n\nThe game can be very short if you don't care about achievements or high score
hoursPlayed:
getting some of the bonus objectives can be time consuming and not worth the hassle.

Conclusion:

I am not the biggest fan of Shoot 'em ups but this game is the perfect pick up and play arcade game to kill some time. Its highly addicting and trying out all the different ship parts to find the right combination that fits your play style is part of the fun.

reviewText:
Another addictive game!!!

The saying ' A second to learn, a lifetime to master ' is a very apt way of putting this game.

You control a plane and the objective is to kill as many jets, planes, battleships, submarines etc as you can, rack up the points aided by reaching a max combo. The controls is what makes this game brilliant, it will certainly test your perception, timing and skill to avoid the barrage of gunfire whilst maintaining your kills to max out your combo for a serious score.

The controls are similar to that old skool game gravity, where you control a small space ship and you have to land it on the landing pad.....right left and down will spin your plane whilst up is your thrusters to fly. Very tricky to master but allows for endless fun in trying to become the best!

Steam achievements supported, also you have in game targets to reach for example, kill 20 jets in one game or reach a score of 5000, when you reach the criteria you can unlock different guns, plane bodies and abilities for your plane that gives you over 100+ different combinations of plane to fly with. Whats better is that every single different combination of aircraft has its own challenges to achieve!!

If your an old skool gamer at heart, this is a no brainer and a must have!!!!! Tons of replayability and content to keep you busy.....question is, are you good enough to be the best Luftrauser?

reviewText:
Luftrausers is fast-paced bullet-hell dogfighter game; you are a plane and you shoot down other planes, missiles, ships and blimps down. Your objective is to survive as long as possible, taking down as many opponents as you can. Game is hard, death can occur within seconds of starting and your score is ranked online.

Moving left or right will change the direction your plane will face, pushing up activates the boosters, and trigger fires your weapon. There is no limit to ammo. Controls are tight, dodging bullets and shooting the enemy has you switching your boosters on and off. You take damage by being shot at by the enemy, flying into enemy planes or ships, and staying too long in the clouds or water. All damage can be repaired by not firing for a few seconds.

You start off with a fast balanced plane, accomplishing objectives tied to your loadout (you can alter the engine, guns and body) and levelling up will unlock new choices. The new body, engine and gun types can be mixed and matched for different combinations, each giving a different play style; turn your ship into a battering ram, attach heat-seeking missiles, drop bombs on enemies below or sink into the sea without taking damage. There are many combinations to try and they do a great job in stopping the game from going stale.

Default colour scheme is light brown, dark red and white; different colour filters can be unlocked (though none of them are to my taste). Music is very good and the sound effects have a nice 'oompf' feel to it.

If there is anything I would like to change is that a few more load out options would be welcomed and the cutscenes would be a bit longer.

TL;DR: hard but fun bullet-hell game. One map, but made highly replayable by combining different parts of the plane.

reviewText:
Luftrauser is a game of physical expression on a two-dimensional plane.

Luftrauser reminds me of three of my all-time favorite games from the spatial-awareness-shooty genre:

1. In Triplane Turmoil, momentum is everything - you have a narrow band of space between ground and sky, and your job is to occupy that space without getting shot down.  You have to maintain motion to keep from nosediving into the rocks, but a good pilot can stall into the perfect place to shoot their sibling's plane and pull out of the dive without taking damage.

2. Crimsonland is top-down bullet hell done right - the bullets" are zombies
date: and the only long-term way to dodge them is by killing them.  The only way to kill them effectively is to internalize the dodging mechanics so that one half of your brain handles the feet

reviewText: LUFTRAUSERS contains some of the most clever mechanics design and balancing you're likely to have seen for a while. Though there are only really three mechanics (Rotate, thrust, shoot), the way they fit together is stunning; releasing thrust is crucial for avoiding enemy fire, and you can only repair damage when you aren't firing yourself. The end result is both chaotic and balletic. Add to this a superb metagame, where you unlock new parts by completing micro-challenges, and it's hard to recommend this game enough.

reviewText:
LUFTRAUSERS! Sorry, I’ve been told by publishers Devolver Digital that LUFTRAUSERS must only be shouted when mentioned. That is true, because LUFTRAUSERS is something to shout about.

LUFTRAUSERS is an indie arcade shooter by developers Vlambeer and the objective of the game is …to shoot everything! Presented as a 2D side-scrolling “wrap around screen” shoot ‘em up similar to old-old school games like 80′s Defender or 90′s Jetstrike your mission is to take to the skies and dodge, dip, dive, duck, dodge and finally BLAST anything that’s BLASTING at you! Enemies will come at you from all directions and in various forms. Ships, carriers and subs take pot shots from the sea and a menagerie of exotic planes (and a Zeppelin!) in the air that will engage in dog fights with you (or try and suicide themselves). As you progress things become more and more hectic to a dizzying degree as the amount going on at once escalates exponentially over 100 levels.

Thankfully as you play the game you complete challenges, level up and gain access to more and more aviation unlocks. In total 125 different combinations of weapons, armour and propulsion systems become available which vary wildly from thicker armour (which naturally gives you more protection, but then decreases your speed), guided missiles (that chase your target but only limited to shooting 4 at a time) or the more wacky “engine that fires bullets when you fly”. This diversity is a unique selling point of the game and getting the knack of each loadout and finding the best configuration to suit you or the scenario is key. For example I’m currently sporting an anti-gravity engine to stay in the air with minimal thrust, a laser which is less powerful than the machine gun but allows for constant damage over time and a light chassis to boost myself out of trouble …which is frequent.

Another plus is that the controls are minimal. No beefy manual on aeronautics or diploma for aerospace engineering required here lads! For the PC version of the game the up arrow gives you forward thrust, left and right turn you in a clockwise or counter-clockwise movement and ‘X’ fires your gun. Stop firing, and your plane repairs itself. Double tap thrust to give you a boost to (hopefully) speed you out of trouble. Simple? Well doing this under fire and the pressure of needing at times some pin-point precession of Maverick, it’s tough and times quite unforgiving.

Visual wise LUFTRAUSERS is presented (for the most part) in a sepia scheme. Images are simple and suitably retro, fitting to its heritage, while audio is catchy and 16-bit. The audible tone to indicate your planes damage and repair progress is a particularly nice touch as it allows players to not have to rely on a visual cue (such as a 100% bar) that could easily be distracting especially when so much is going on.

Overall LUFTRAUSERS is another great example of an indie title that I’m sure will be recognised for its achievements. It’s (Warning: Indie Game Cliché Alert!) easy to learn, fun to play, cheap (which is important in this day and age) and has a good re-playability. Recommended if you’re a fan of the genre or have the change and looking for something to while away your time with when not wanting to drop robots from the sky.

reviewText:
LUFTRAUSERS! Sorry, I’ve been told by publishers Devolver Digital that LUFTRAUSERS must only be shouted when mentioned. That is true, because LUFTRAUSERS is something to shout about.

LUFTRAUSERS is an indie arcade shooter by developers Vlambeer and the objective of the game is …to shoot everything! Presented as a 2D side-scrolling “wrap around screen” shoot ‘em up similar to old-old school games like 80′s Defender or 90′s Jetstrike your mission is to take to the skies and dodge, dip, dive, duck, dodge and finally BLAST anything that’s BLASTING at you! Enemies will come at you from all directions and in various forms. Ships, carriers and subs take pot shots from the sea and a menagerie of exotic planes (and a Zeppelin!) in the air that will engage in dog fights with you (or try and suicide themselves). As you progress things become more and more hectic to a dizzying degree as the amount going on at once escalates exponentially over 100 levels.

Thankfully as you play the game you complete challenges, level up and gain access to more and more aviation unlocks. In total 125 different combinations of weapons, armour and propulsion systems become available which vary wildly from thicker armour (which naturally gives you more protection, but then decreases your speed), guided missiles (that chase your target but only limited to shooting 4 at a time) or the more wacky “engine that fires bullets when you fly”. This diversity is a unique selling point of the game and getting the knack of each loadout and finding the best configuration to suit you or the scenario is key. For example I’m currently sporting an anti-gravity engine to stay in the air with minimal thrust, a laser which is less powerful than the machine gun but allows for constant damage over time and a light chassis to boost myself out of trouble …which is frequent.

Another plus is that the controls are minimal. No beefy manual on aeronautics or diploma for aerospace engineering required here lads! For the PC version of the game the up arrow gives you forward thrust, left and right turn you in a clockwise or counter-clockwise movement and ‘X’ fires your gun. Stop firing, and your plane repairs itself. Double tap thrust to give you a boost to (hopefully) speed you out of trouble. Simple? Well doing this under fire and the pressure of needing at times some pin-point precession of Maverick, it’s tough and times quite unforgiving.

Visual wise LUFTRAUSERS is presented (for the most part) in a sepia scheme. Images are simple and suitably retro, fitting to its heritage, while audio is catchy and 16-bit. The audible tone to indicate your planes damage and repair progress is a particularly nice touch as it allows players to not have to rely on a visual cue (such as a 100% bar) that could easily be distracting especially when so much is going on.

Overall LUFTRAUSERS is another great example of an indie title that I’m sure will be recognised for its achievements. It’s (Warning: Indie Game Cliché Alert!) easy to learn, fun to play, cheap (which is important in this day and age) and has a good re-playability. Recommended if you’re a fan of the genre or have the change and looking for something to while away your time with when not wanting to drop robots from the sky.

reviewText:
Luftrausers is an action game where you fly an aircraft while completing missions and unlocking new parts. The goal is to get the highest score, by avoiding incoming rockets, planes and bullets. Kill enough enemies in one combo or reach a certain score and you'll unlock new parts for your aircraft. These parts might just help you get an even higher score. The parts are finely tuned and expertly balanced, so for example, increasing your damage might just make your aircraft fly/manoeuvre slower. You have to take things like that into account before taking off. You can adjust your engine, your weapon and your body and there are plenty of parts to unlock and use.
Luftrausers is a fun game with some good music that's probably best played in smaller sessions.

[Rating: 77/100]

reviewText: LUFTRAUSERS or also know as LoveTrousers" is a Sudo2d sidescroller (everything is actually rendered 3D made to look like 2d pixel art). In this game you fly a plane which I can only be assume to be consdier a Rauser. Durring your time in the game you will encounter many enimies and will be constantly outnumber and outguned. date:
thanks to nutty Sciencetist on your base ship your Rauser not only a litteral terror of the skies but also has the ablity to heal  yourslef when not fireing your main gun.

The 1st thing that might intrest you is that you unlock parts of 3 interchangable catagories. Gun/Body/Engine. Each one of these catagories have a total of about 6 parts (I think) with the 6th of each catagory being an absolute grind of mental and pysical will to optain.    Each part is tied to its own Soundline for the game main soundtrack
recommended:
which means each design you have will result in a slight variant of the theme which is pretty cool IMO
Also Each set of parts are given its own individual name (Which is around 6x6x6=216 names if you count up all the cobination)

The 2nd thing that might intrest you that the game has many color plannets presets which you unlock via the missions attach to each part (Makes the game look completly diffrent for better or worse).
Before I forget each part is tied to a mission of goal to achieve durring you run which leads to the general idea of more stuff and maybe a next mission if havn't completed a part's misson. The game will hold back on giving you more missions when you hit a roadblock which ussusally involves killing a certain enemy unit.

The 3rd thing that might intrest you with this game is that the matches themselves are very quick (around 3-7 mins depending on mode and skill). Which makes it a perfect game to just play a match to put down before you need to go BUT there is an issue with this game being extremly addicting as you get into it. Be sure to watch the clock while you're playing because on more than 1 occasion I played for hours non-stop untill it was 5am in the morning or I began to develope an headache

reviewText:
Luftrausers is the delightful ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of Top Gun and Asteroids.
At it's core it's a game where you fly a customizable plane and shoot down other planes and sink battleships, with the occasional blimp if you're aptly skilled.
This next installment in from the indie powerhouse, Vlambeer, offers everything that they specialize in; pure high octane action and a childlike sense of amazement. As you rocket into the clouds with the hordes of enemy aces behind you, the engines on your plane cut as you begin to turn to face your oponents, but this is no accident. You push the throttle to the limit and fire your high powered laser beam cutting swathes through the sky. Fixated on the visceral and aerial carnage that encompasses your field of view, you pull out of your dive slicing the enemies to scrap with your custom bladed hull. All of this took place in a timespan of about 10 seconds, welcome to Luftrausers.

The music done by the amazingly talented Jukio Kallio (Kozilek) sets the tone for the aeronautical carnage, every different part for your plane (over 100 different combinations by the way) creates a new soundtrack for you to enter the danger zone to.

Luftrausers is really damn good and for $9.99, an absolute steal and must have for any armchair adrenaline junkies.

I would write more about the game, but I want to go back to playing it.

Do yourselves a favor and pick up Luftrausers

Raus/10

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HGW9E3su9XY
For me, LUFTRAUSERS is a game that exemplifies the current 'indie craze' of being lauded for artistic style in place of actual content. In a way it's a sign of change (and in a good way at that) that these types of games are getting main stream recognition, but in another lifetime it feels like LUFTRAUSERS would have just been a flash game, and would have been free.

LUFTRAUSERS gimmick is its sepia hued. That’s basically it. Though you can unlock different hues, I never played with them, they looked awful.

Yes the world has moved on from flash portals and those kinds of games now have a new home called the App Store. So yes, it’s not outrageous in itself to be charging money for this style of game, but I do have issue with the amount. If I'd paid around £2, like many a game on the App Store, I'd have played it and walked away and felt like I got my money's worth, not saying I would have enjoyed it more, but I wouldn't have felt like I should have expected more. At £6.99 I feel like I should be getting more of a return for my investment.

All the incentive to play is; score attack and fulfilling objectives like ‘kill x of y’ or ‘get a score of z’, but that doesn’t really change how you’re going to play the game, you were going to be doing those anyway. The score attack or the objectives (I was never really clear which) unlock equipment for your plane, and while the game may boast more than 125 combinations, there's little incentive from the game itself to mix it up, just your own desire to experiment. Also, the later upgrades suck for the most part, for example the 'homing' missiles need a lot of coaxing to avoid them just nose diving into the sea.

And that's fundamentally my problem; the game isn't much fun. You play within a single area, that appears to loop, that's quite tall, though enemy boats at the bottom can shoot you at the top of it, so flying to the top is only a disadvantage to yourself. The controls are simple, (though menu navigation is a chore as the button that accesses a given menu changes depending on current screen) yet somehow it never feels like you have complete control, it's only possible to make fine changes to direction, or complete changes, it feels like there's no mid ground, which makes trying to manoeuvre a pain. There are a number of different enemies, but there’s a gradual build up to the stronger enemies that the game follows, so in a game where you're expected to die a lot, you're going to see the same few over, and over, and over. Also, get used to that background music, you're going to be hearing that same small part of it every time too...

The game is certainly functional, and I guess that’s something to praise with the modern indie craze, a game being released in a non 'early access' form, but there's so little content provided and a generic shoot-'em-up experience at best.

reviewText:
Luftrausers is surprisingly good. Incredibly good, even. You start it up for the first time and within a minute of playing it you'll be smiling broadly and wishing that every game could be as viscerally enjoyable as this one.

The controls have been honed to perfection. Simply flying around with the aircraft (is it called a Luftrauser?) is pleasing to the senses. Throughout the game, you'll unlock new parts that you can use to customize your plane, which come with both benefits and drawbacks. Here's where the true brilliance of the design comes in. Each part of the ship has its own instruments to add to the song that plays during the game, and each part has multiple missions that you can only complete with that part. So each combination of parts - and there's at least a hundred - offers a unique experience. To top it all off, every aircraft you can possibly assemble with these components has its own nickname, such as the Nightmare, the Tuberauser, or my current favorite, the Warturtle.

It's cheap, it's intense, and it's extremely challenging. If you like shooters of any kind, consider Luftrausers a solid purchase.

reviewText: omg i don't know where to start.... i love Nuclear throne... or whatever that game is called... and thru those forums i heard about this one ... and so i checked it out... and this game is like rogue legacy in the sense that its so bloody addictive... you know those counterstrike moments one more round one more round just one more round and after hours and your wayyyy too late for whatever social or work engagement you had is just poof gone.. well this game does that for me... and for 5$ or whatever its going for its a steal, i can point out tonnes of games for 60 that arent worth crap.. this game is hot, unlocks, missions, tonnes of deaths, kill stats, weird guns, guns, guns guns, there is an insane super hard mode that i've still not grasped,,, either way if you are bored and on the line with this one take the plunge you will not regret it.. this game is AWESOME !!! and if this post made you try it please let me know, I love when people tell me that i've helped them find gems that have turned into endless time blackholes....... ( ohhh god alpha centari . damn you sid meyers.... ) anyways give this a shot, you will love it, its so much fun, and its great because theres luck , blind silly luck and skill, and trust me its fun learning to get better.... buy holy god battleships, experimental planes, ace enemy pilots missile subs and dreaded deregibles.... oh m,an... yeah buy this game !!!

reviewText:
Reasons to get this game.
#1. It's a classic, arcade like game.
#2. Very simple controls, easy to play, and very fun.
#3. HOLY ♥♥♥♥ THIS GAME IS INTENSE.
#4. It has the best ♥♥♥♥ing soundtrack ever.
#5. Your Rauser (Your Plane), is fully customisible.
#6. You get to play as the Luftwaffe. ( I don't know if that matters but I think it's cool. :3 )
#7. There's action everywhere you look on the screen.  This includes planes crashing, missles flying everywhere, battleships exploding, submarines submurging, blimps decending, bullets flying, and much more.
#8. Theres are so many good things about this game I can't even fit them on the list.

reviewText:
Guys.
Seriously guys. If you like score driven games where you're pitted against the world in a 2D arcade type game, you will genuinely love, adore and play this for hours! I was a little sceptical about it when installing it to see it was only 93 mb, but it's like a badass flash game that really deserves the $$$$ spent. The content within overweighs the stigma of price easily as you find yourself piecing your fighter plane with a NUKE FOR A BODY as well as a SUPER FAST ENGINE to give you SPEEDY ANGLING so you can shoot your enemies with LASER BEAMS.

11/10. Buy this game for many hours of fun.

reviewText:
This is a Luftrauser, it rauses luft.

A great shoot-em-up with unique mechanics and innovative customization. You could make your plane as a slow, missile launching juggernaut, or a frail, high speed kamikaze aircraft, the choices are up to your imagination.

Great soundtracks, neat visual, and challenging gameplay.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have not been playing this game for long but already i love it. I like the variety of planes and ships you fight and the gameplay mechanics are very fun. However the only problem with the game for me is that when i close the game and try to play it again steam says the game is already running. And the only way i can play the game again is to switch my laptop off and on again which is a real pain in the ♥♥♥! I would be extremely happy if the developer would fix this bug becase i love this game soooooo much! :D However the bug is really annoying.

In Luftrausers you can unlock differant parts for your rauser such as differant engines, guns and various other things such as better armour or a new part that makes your plane not get damaged by water or clashing with other enemies. You will unlock these parts as you complete levels. To complete levels you will have to complete tasks such as killing a certain number of enemies or killing one big powerful enemy that takes longer to kill. The basic enemies in the game consist of small fighter planes that dont get in the way to much but as you start to progress heavier more deadly fighters will attack you as well as naval ships and even a huge blimp!

There is a normal difficulty setting and an extra hard difficulty so there is plenty of challenges to complete.Luftrausers is a dogfighting/bullet hell game in which you will have to create tactics to dodge enemy bullets and shells. Another thing to mention is that by changing around your rauser parts the soundtrack also changes and throughout the game you will also be able to unlock various colour filters. I rate this game a 7.5 /10 (A very fun game with a good sountrack and replayability)

(update as of 11/01/15) The bug i was having trouble with was fixed a month or so back. Now i can enjoy the game without any problems.

reviewText: This is a pretty interesting shooter. The controls take some getting use to, but once you do, you'll find a really fun game with numerous enemies to shoot, challenges to accomplish and upgrades to unlock. The soundtrack's not too bad, either.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: There is no comparison to how badass one can feel when dipping and diving through swarms of bullets and enemies all in retro shmup goodness. This really is one hell of a game and I'd reccomend everyone and anyone give it a shot and to get up on those leaderboards. It handles very much like asteroids except with gravity, however asteroids handled terribly and this title manages to pull of the same concept but with complete finesse creating a hardcore and hard to master gameplay mechanic but with a simplistic 2 button control scheme (well one button and the arrow keys). There is really only one thing I could even come remotely close to criticism and that would be the story. Of course I can't hold this against luftrausers as it is a retro title meant for quick hardcore dosage and not meant to be taken too seriously in terms of setting. However this mini world in which it is set is fun, interesting and even the mini characters are so humorously designed that to see them come to life with some little bits of dialogue would make this a gem. Put that £59 in a bank and forget titanfall, get yourself a copy of this wonderful game filled with white knuckle, hardcore, skill based, retro, airborne, score chasing awesomness, not even mentioning the crazy boss enemies who patrol the skies littering the screen with lead.

reviewText:
A full featured Bullet Hell flash game: simple arcade fun.

Worthy of being a purchasable title because of the sheer Game Design excellence:
+ the elegance of the gravity/stall mechanic
+ uncluttered interface: eg. gauge your health from blockout grey shading
+ health regen by not firing  -vs- combo meter
+ thrill of dog-fighting" against most AI enemy
+ interesting achievements-to-unlock system

Still has some hangovers from being a basic flash game.
- music variety?
- menu navigation is poor
- gamepad integration?

Get Luftrausers on sale."

reviewText:
LuftRausers is basically a really focused arcade game. It doesn't do a lot, but what it does, it does really well. The game plays kind of like Asteroids except there is constant gravity pulling you towards the water. The customizable Rauser is pretty cool. You pick a weapon system such as a machinegun, a continuous laser, spread shot that pushes you back, homing missiles, etc), a body (high health but low agility, you take no ramming damage but have little health, drops bombs but slow health regen, etc) and an engine (heavy thrust but poor turning while thrusting, near anti-gravity, no damage entering the water, etc) and then you just fight nonstop waves of enemies trying to rack up as many points as possible. Each combination has its own nickname and each part has little achievements tied to it too.

The gameplay is pretty frantic, as the sky quickly becomes filled with enemies and bullets. Thankfully you can take a decent amount of punishment before dying (unless you're using the melee part) and you regenerate health whenever you're not shooting.

The variety you can get while building your Rauser is impressive, a few of the builds I liked was a Rauser equipped with a heavy, slow firing cannon, the melee body, and the water engine. I'd just dive bomb ships and fire the cannon just before I rammed the ship and plunged into the water, even the battleships can't take too many hits from that. Of course, if I timed it wrong I'd fly right into their gunfire and be blown apart (melee body can take 2 maybe 3 hits from full before dying). Another cool Rauser I had success with was the Beam Laser, Bomb Body, and Original" balanced engine. I'd just zip around dodging enemies and bullets and slice ships and planes to ribbons.

You don't have to grind too much for the parts either
date: I think I've basically unlocked almost all the parts (except one special one for each section I think
recommended: the padlock symbol looks different than the one for the rest I unlocked) in only about 2 hours of play I'd say. One additional neat thing is that the music changes depending on your parts selection. Its the same basic theme every time
hoursPlayed: but different parts use different "instruments". The music is pretty good too
voteText: IMO
helpfulPercent: though it might become repetitive quickly for some.\n\nOnly managed to reach (what I assume) is the "Boss" A massive war zeppelin once. The game is quite difficult. I could see this being an actual arcade game from 15-20 years ago easily
votesHelpful: though given how difficult it is
votesTotal: it better have had extra lives per credit. Either way it would've munched my quarters ♥♥♥♥ing fast. This thing is fun.\n\nTL:DR Luftrausers Owns. Awesome Arcade style game
votesFunny: great gameplay
commentsCount: cool music

reviewText:
LUFTRAUSERS brings all the glorious fun and fast paced action to the sky with bullet hell elements and retro graphics.

You can customize your aircraft that better suits your goal before every launch.
In each launch you need to fullfill certain requirements depending what part you equipped to gain access to new parts and new goals.
After completing some challenges you unlock the SFMT mode, which is way harder and challenge the player to it's edge.

An overall great game that looks simple and short but in the end offers fun and good challenges.

reviewText: Hardcore 2D bullet-hell arcade game. 'Nuff said.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Luftrausers is a 2D Arcade-Style Bullet Hell Shooter. You take control of a single fighter jet, holding off thousand of planes, jets, boats, and submarines until you die. It's essentially achieving the highest score you possibly can. This game isn't easy, it's hard, but mastering is where the game shines.

This game is simple at it's core, but it's filled to the brim with fast paced, non-stop action, sure to get your adrenaline going. You don't fly this thing normally. You can turn it left, right, and accelerate by holding up. This means you can keep your fighter in the air for a good amount of time if you take advantage of the momentum. For enemies, you have your simple planes and boats, but stronger variants pop up, like battleships that have massive HP and fire a barrage of bullets, or aces in the sky with very accurate aim. You need to keep your wits about you, so dodge and shoot your way to victory. Shooting isn't the only way to kill enemies either, you can also ram into enemies for some massive damage, as the expense of losing health quickly. Your health is regenerative, so the way you recover it is to simply not fire your weapon.

However, the best part about this game is the customization. There are literally 125 ways to build your fighter. You can change the weapon, body, and engine, each with their own perks and disadvantages. This makes the game accustomed to have so many different play styles, so you can see which one fits to your choosing. You can have a powerful tank with a cannon and heavy armor, have a super fast engine with a laser beam for quick aiming, or you can have a kamikaze style fighter with massive impact damage and explode spectacularly upon death.

With all these parts, also come missions for each individual part. This gives the player the chance to try out new pieces and accomplish a goal while doing so. Think of it as a reward for trying new things, and testing your skils. It extends replay ability as well.

After you've messed around in normal mode long enough, there's another mode called SFMT, which is essentially hard mode. Battleships, Aces, and more enemies spawn right at the beginning, and it's as frantic as you can imagine, and you WILL die quickly. If you've mastered normal mode, try your skills at SFMT, and see how long you can survive Hell.

Overall, Luftrausers is an incredible arcade style game with blood pumping action that never stops with so much customization in one package. This game is definitely worth full price, and you'll have an awesome time if you enjoy a good challenge.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It's really one of the few indie games that I think is overrated. The combat loses its luster after 10-15  minutes of playtime even with the varied weapons. Also, the system they have set up is not very intriguing or enticing toward investing more time than about 2-4 hours. You just keep going until the amount of guys on the screen is overwhleming and hope that when you die you've done some stuff you haven't before. That's it. That is literally the game.\n\nOverral I'd say 2/5, with the main appeal being the art-house WWI persepctive of a 2-d plane game. I got this for 6-7 $ and I'd say that along with Ultionus: A Poor Single Play DOS Game, it is one of the disappointments of the spring `14 indie releases and I wouldnt buy unless it's < 2$.

reviewText: Relive the harrowing experience of flying in the Pacific during World War 2 in this incredibly realistic military flight simulator that rival's the genre's best (Microsoft Combat Simulator, X-Wing vs Tie Fighter). Fly in dozens of different real life planes, painstakingly rendered in lush 3D using hundreds of references taken from the Smithsonian's air museum.\n\nFor added realism, use a wireless keyboard with low batteries. You'll never know when the keyboard stops responding, representing an engine stall that American pilots often faced in the heat of battle due to the low quality of their engine parts.

reviewText:
Fun to play. Difficult to master. Extremely difficult to complete.

Luftrausers is a retro-styled arcade shooter that controls well and keeps the upgrades unlocking at a nice pace. These upgrades are a good selection of weapons, flight styles and armour/mods. It's enjoyable trying them all out too see how they work and how they can adapt your play style and each of the 125 combinations has it's own unique aircraft name ... a really nice touch.

Your enemies range from enemy aircraft with different weapons (I hate the enemy aces armed with lasers, you will too), ships, submarines and the main objective to completing the game ... the Blimp".

As I said before

reviewText:
An excellent game !

Pure arcade game. The controls are simple, and you should feel immediately taken by the frantic gameplay. Each play will last between 10s and a few minutes, depending on how good you are at dodging the endless streams of enemies bullets. But of course, you will want more, and in a few seconds you will be up in the air again trying to beat your previous score.

You might think that this wouldn't be fun for hours if you're not into getting the highscore" mentality. But Vlambeer (the studio who developped LUFTRAUSERS)
date: manage to take that simple idea of an arcade dogfighting game
recommended: and add something more.\n\nYour plane has 3 parts (Gun
voteText: Engine) which you will soon be able to modify. There are 5 different parts of each type
helpfulPercent: which allow for lots of variation. More importantly
votesHelpful: most parts are "side-grades"
votesTotal: which mean unlocked parts are not better
votesFunny: but different than the original parts. Each part requires you to adapt your gameplay
commentsCount: and will offer different strengths and weaknesses.\n\nTo encourage you to try all the parts
column16: each part is linked to several "missions"
column17: which are challenges you can accomplish with that part. For example "Killing 5 different enemies types in a single game"
column20: etc... Theses are not mandatory
column21: but will allow you to unlock other parts and a few other hidden stuff.\n\nWhile trying to perform theses challenges
column22: you will get to understand the different parts better
column23: and find that some suits you better than others. I've often dismissed a specific part as weak
column24: until i tried to complete its missions and figured out how to best use it (which part should go with which
column25:
and how to adapt my gameplay to the new plane). My 3 best scores have been with 3 different planes.

Also it's very telling that in forum threads asking "what's the best plane for doing X ?" all theses answers will vary wildly. There is no "best" plane. It's all about personal tastes and how you use each plane. So congratulations to Vlambeer for managing to balance all theses parts together.

All of that means that
column27: there is that metagame to try to finish all missions. It may or may not please everybody
column28: but i know it keeps me playing way more than a basic "aim for the highscore" game would.\n\nIt's quite easy to unlock all parts
column29: so no player should frustrated that they lack part
column31: unlocking everything is gonna be a true challenge. Achievements stats show that less than 1% of players have managed to finish all missions."

reviewText:
This game is absolutely fantastic. The controls are tight and gameplay is simple yet addicting. The only problem I can see with it is how short it is, seeing as how I got most things with an hour of playing. Despite this it still proves to be entertaining when I need a good pick me up. One thing I attribute to this would be the soundtrack. Fairly simple tunes yet oh so satisfying with each cockpit, body, and engine giving a new combination of music for over an amount of 125 different ship and song combinations. Like most other Vlambeer games I have played this is short but overall amazing and really fun and quirky.

I highly recommend this game if you are a fan of bullet hell games or games that have awesome soundtracks. If you like this game I would also recommend checking out Vlambeer's other games as they all offer something good.
10/10 I would love to play for the first time again.

reviewText:
This game is a must have if you want very good controls, the living hell out of bullets in the sky and the Feeling like a boss if you beat an damn airship out of the sky.
The game is very hard and you need to find your personal mix out of weapon and Rauser.
You can play as a super weak shotgun rauser which cant get hit by planes flying through him.
Or you can play as a slow, heavy Rauser with very much health.
The weapons are all well done.
The Soundtrack of the game is epic, dont need to say any more words.
If you like the style of the game, buy it. if not, buy it.
I would recommend this game for EVERYONE who wants even just a little challenge in games.

reviewText:
Do you enjoy danmaku (bullet-hell)? How about customisable aircraft? Or do you just want to have some fun?

If you answered yes to any one of those questions you'll probably love LUTRAUSERS.
Paying tribute to an era of arcade shmups it's one of the best gameplay focused games to come out in recent memory.

With hours worth of challenges, and loads of parts to unlock for your Luftrauser, it's well worth the $10. Above all else though, it's just plain, straight up fun. Wether you're dodging bullets flying at you from every corner of the screen, or plowing through enemies with your aircraft alone, you'll have tons of fun with this game.

reviewText: Obligatory header to the review: I focus on four primary areas whenever I review a game: gameplay, story, graphics, and sound/audio/general things that go into your earholes. Gameplay and Story get a rating scale from 1 to 10, and the AV stuff gets a rating from 1 to 5. My philosophy on this is that there are some instances in which a game may not necessarily have that much in the way of gameplay (take Amnesia for example), but the story/atmosphere/whatever it may be is reason enough to pick it up. Also, take the cumulative score with a grain of salt; it's just a numerical feeling about the game as a whole. That's part of why I do these subscores. Also, keep in mind that I'm not going off of school grade based rankings. A 5/10 denotes what I feel to be an average game. Likewise, 7/10 is a game that I think is pretty cool, and something that gets a 2/10 is near-abomination level. Pinning scores to an even further obfuscated rating scale is kinda senseless, but for the sake of my backloggery, I'll repeat again that 1.0-2.7 is a one-star game, 3.0-4.7 is a two-star game, 5.0-6.7, 7.0-8.7, and 9.0-10 are three, four, and five stars, respectively.\n\nGameplay: Vlambeer has always been good at creating really simple yet excellently controlling games, and Luftrausers is certainly no exception. Essentially, you have four buttons: acceleration, boost left and right, and fire. You do have a health meter
date:
which is represented by a white circle closing in on you before you eventually die, which can be replenished by letting go of the fire button and not getting hit for a little bit. Speaking of death, this game is pretty tough. It certainly has that arcade style quarter munching level of difficulty. However, death is only a minor setback, as it only takes two to three seconds to get back into the action after dying. An average run won't last you much longer than two or three minutes, though.

Another aspect of this game is the customizable ship parts. You can get up to six guns, engines, and bodies, each with their own respective weaknesses and strengths. It is these parts, as well as the challenges associated with each and every part, that make Luftrausers much more than the simple arcade shooter I thought it was when I first saw it. There is actually a remarkable amount of depth for such a seemingly simple shooter (yes, that alliteration was intentional). My biggest complaint about the game - and it may seem minor, but it caused God knows how many deaths - is that every time you get hit, there is a frame or two of pausing. It stacks up whenever you're trying to manoeuvre your way through a hail of bullets. This is probably an intentional programming thing, as a ninety-some-megabyte game should not lag an i5-3470.

Other than that, I really don't have any big time complaints. Also, SFMT mode made me cry in the corner out of sheer terror. I haven't completed all of the missions yet, and I still haven't unlocked the [Classified] as of the time of writing this, but I've gotten far enough into the game that I feel that I am able to give it fair enough of a review. For only one big small" quibble
recommended: I give the gameplay in this game a 9/10.\n\nStory: This is one of the times where I don't bother to review the game on story
hoursPlayed: since there really isn't any. Instead
voteText: I'll just skip on to the graphics and not factor in a score for story into the final score.\n\nGraphics: One of the great things about applying a minimalist aesthetic is that it allows the artist to apply all sorts of subtle touches
helpfulPercent: and that's what makes this game great: it's filled to the brim with subtle touches that make it just great. For instance
votesHelpful: when you're coming in over the water
votesTotal: how hard you're coming in affects the wake.Another subtle touch is the flames that come off of the aces whenever they are at low health. Overall
votesFunny: the pixel art in this game is just fantastic
commentsCount: and is definitely a good example of how to do considerable things with a minimal color pallete. For graphics
column16: I'll give it a 5/5
column17: 'cuz it just looks great.\n\nMusic: At its most basic level
column18: there's only two songs in the game (the menu song and the combat song). However
column20: there's about 126 songs in the game. How I can come up with that number is that there are 125 different ship combinations. Each part adds a different element to the base song. It's not a subtle thing
column21: either; you can tell whenever a part you've put on changes the song
column22: and all of them add pretty cool touches to the song. If you're switching parts every now and then
column23: you most certainly won't get tired of the soundtrack. I know I didn't
column24: and that's why I'm giving it a 5/5 for the incredibly dynamic soundtrack.\n\nOverall rating: 9/5/5; 9.5/10. I can see why this game took so long to develop: there's a remarkable amount of polish to this game. Also
column25: if you think $10 is too much
column26: don't. The game really is worth the money (even more so on sale). It's very playable  and has that "I need to kill ten minutes so here's a game" appeal."

reviewText:
Fun little arcade game. Great if you only have a little time play, but can easily cause hours to slip away! Hey, that rhymed...

Anyways, some highlights include:
-catchy sound track that changes slightly with each differnt Rauser combination.
-extensive amount of combinations to choose from including a random mode
-easy to play, hard to master. Each new combination slightly changes how the Rauser handles
-Weapon, body and engine specific missions that always give you something to shoot for (yes, pun intended. Deal with it)
-More unlockable than you can shake a stick at!

The gameplay does get a bit repetitive after playing awhile, but seiously, how much are you expecting from an INDIE game!? I usually play a round or two, get bored/fed up, play something else and then come back for another few quick rounds. It's like your favorite snack food. You wouldn't want to make a meal out of it, but when you've in the mood it's a tastey little treat!

reviewText: The fact that there are no public reviews of this game do it an injustice. I recall reading an article from the guy who designed it (I think on kotaku.com) where he said they made it when they were at a dark place in their lives... and well, World War style games are like that, and even if they may regret being at a dark place, the game itself is worth playing and supporting. I want to see more from this studio when they are at a bright and happy place.\n\nI may not have played this game as long as I've played others, but I believe this is one of the greatest casual games I've played on steam. And when I say casual" what I mean is a "pick up and play" game - you don't have to spend hours min/maxing your characters
date: grinding reputations... you just go out there and Rouse.\n\nWhen you unlock different parts for your Rouser each part has it's own challenges - and when you complete them you get harder and harder ones
recommended: so if eventually you get to one you're not doing great on
hoursPlayed: just switch to another part that may have easier challenges
voteText: do those
helpfulPercent: get better at the game
votesHelpful: then go back and do the harder ones you were stuck on before.\n\nThe gameplay feels responsive
votesTotal: and "Rousing" as it's called where you essentially turn off the engine and free fall feels great; dodging cannonfire and enemy missiles only to re-ignite the engines seconds later to gain a burst of speed. It feels great.\n\nThe soundtrack is ace too; I can't think of any recent game that's made me think "This music is kicking!" but this does. I'd liken it to the "Jets'n'Guns Soundtrack" by Machinae Supremacy... however please note
votesFunny: the soundtrack to Jets'n'Guns is great... the game... utter poo-poo. It's available on steam
commentsCount: but I'd say listen to the soundtrack on Spotify and ignore the game.\n\nWell enough of me rambling. Buy Luftrrausers. Rause those Lufts!"

reviewText: Great arcade game. Fun flying and shooting mechanics, different combinations of weapons and ship part unlocks. Challenging game. Decent variety of enemies but expect to be getting very familiar with most. Quite hard gameplay but very addicting. Despite very simple controls the learning curve goes up steep for the first hour then flattens a little for a decent time as you get slightly better, completing challenges and unlocking parts (and colour schemes)...and then it explodes up again. Don't even bother with SFMT unless you are ninja at bullet hell. I really love the main game though, only game on my work computer, not that I get a chance to play it. Which is why I have it all my vitas too. Buy. Let go of fire to heal. The game microfreezes to when you get hit as an indicator.

reviewText: Looking for a new twist on some classic arcade style dogfighting shoot-em-ups? Look no further than Luftrausers. This slick 8-bit style shooter can keep you entertained for a long time, whether you're trying to unlock every part and achievement or trying to up your highscore just that little bit more. The controls are smooth and precise and the stalling and gravity mechanic adds a new level of depth and control over your aircraft over other similar games. Plane customization, finding that perfect combo of weapon, body, and engine for your play style also adds to the depth and replayability. And the music! Different combinations of parts also change up the soundtrack, all variations on a common theme. Many a times I had to fight the urge to break into goosesteping while rocking out to its tunes. You'll get a lot of bang for your buck in Luftrausers and well worth any price it’s at, sale or not.

reviewText:
Quite honestly one of the best arcade games I've ever played.  At the time of writing I have seven hours played and I only just installed it today.  Couple of guys over for thanksgiving and we just played this to no end, getting nearly everything but that darn blimp!

It's just so much fun to dive-bomb ships, surprise them from underwater, spin around aimlessly firing lazers into the air and just mercilessly destroying little ships as they attempt to bring down your rampage.

Fully worth the $5, even better if it's on sale, and even better if it's played with friends

reviewText:
(7.5/10)

The arcade action is just about what you could have hoped for, along with some decent strategy and personal skill progress via the various different upgrade combinations.

The aesthetic is also incredibly cool and sort of that modernist retro that has been the rage lately.  Both visually and musically the tone is set quite richly and its hard not to enjoy all the subtle little touches like the main theme song as you play changing based on how you configured your fighter.

Its not necessarily spilling over with replayability.  The overall game is a bit fun but progress is rather limited in the 'finish one of these several goals' task completion.  Once you have finished all of the base tasks, there is another layer of incredibly ridiculously hard that opens up but its honestly *so* over the top its more worth trying for a few laughs at its utter futility.

The one last comment is that honestly I was not a fan of the controls *at all*.  While the basic flight mechanic is quite well executed, the game screams out for really solid gamepad support, and it was just not quite there.  While basic gamepad control is possible, its not very customizable and the configurations that you are presented with simply didn't work that well for me.  I ended up setting the gamepad down and just using the keyboard because in the end it was easier to manage.

reviewText: LUFTRAUSERS is a delightful mix of classic arcade shooter action and modern sensibilities, Atari style graphics with a high-res flourish and a World War II Nazi-chic aesthetic, all set to a thumping, crunchy, retro-neue military soundtrack. But above all, this game is challenging and fun. While the controls are simple, they take time to master, yet they're intuitive enough to feel natural. Each enemy has its own unique challenges to overcome, and choas reigns after a few minutes of sustained gameplay as the screen fills with planes, jets, ships and bullets, with a few boss enemies to overcome beside. Whats more, the game has near-endless replayability, as accumulating points and passing in-game missions rewards you with parts to customize your Rauser with for different gameplay styles. If you're a fan of shoot-'em-ups, I would highly recommended this game.

reviewText:
I really fell in love with this game, and for around eight hours I really had a blast. It's a simple game with good controls, and I find being able to move well in a 2d game like this just addictive, so I've spent my money's worth of time on this. The game starts off rather challenging already, and I found that getting around required actual thought, and made me develop a lot of tactics for different planes, which feels pretty rewarding.

Then, for another eight hours, I tried going through the rest of the 'late game' achievements and some of its little flaws start to really shine. I'm still sitting here trying this actually, with the game cut to .3 of its' original speed.
The whole system is based off getting a combo killing enemies, yet the flawed spawning rates sometimes leave me with only one enemy on screen which I can barely kill after around 12 or so normal enemies, which absolutely disappear.
There's also some flaws in the whole 'bullet hell with tank-controls' when some enemies can create whole walls which you just have to hope you pass through. These will also take up all of this 'spawn cap' so it's a huge block for no progress.

Aaand while I did enjoy the game, it's rather simplistic and the customizeable mechanics aren't very well balanced. I'm a bit sore about the whole thing right now, but I don't think I can recommend this at ten dollars, at least.
