reviewText:
BEST CONTROLS EVER


This is a fun game that feels great, you can pull of insane moves and dodges, all with a very simple control system that feels just right and you just feel like a badass when you triple flip to kill an ace, shoot down a jet and pull up in time to see your thrusters reflect in the water. And pulling this off is quite easy but still feels satisfying every time, adding to this is the customization of the planes which all offer their unique playstyles and cool soundtracks. For fans of bullet hell cahos and tryhards there is the insane SFMT mode which starts everything at the highest difficulty, it even has an achievment to survive for the first 15 seconds or so and it is brutal. If you are just looking for a little fun or want to play a challenging bullet hell game then this is for you.

reviewText: Have you ever wanted to be an 8-bit fighter pilot? Well, LUFTRAUSERS is the game for you! Set to a brilliant soundtrack, the gameplay of LUFTRAUSERS is brilliant and highly satisfying. Short games that you want to keep coming back to is what you'll get with this game, with different unlockable customizations to make you the ultimate dogfighter. This game is all about those exciting moments where, with barely any health left, you manage to get the edge on your enemy and triumph after all. Whether you are a fan of Vlambeer's previous, Ridiculous Fishing; an arcade-style junkie; or just looking to have a fun-filled evening, you can't go wrong with LUFTRAUSERS.

reviewText:
Incredibly good.

Might not last very long. Not sure, although I already also played quite a bit of the free html5 or whatever version (it's very limited, only the standard plane and very few enemies). I've already unlocked all the different parts now, within 2 hrs. Although I haven't done all the challenges per plane part variant.

The planes are made up of three different sections, and for all the sections you can choose from 4-5 different parts which you unlock as you go. Unlocking is inevitable as it's tied to an unseen score total. Even if you only get a couple of thousand points per life it tallies your all time point total and levels you up at different numbers not too far apart.

All the different plane parts have challenges tied to them, I am not sure how deep these challenges go, but there must at least be 5 challenges per part? Since the plane consists of three parts you have three different challenges active at all times. The challenges is stuff like take out x amount of total enemies or one specific enemy, or do this many points. These can be both single life based or totaled up like the levelling, it says in the text what exactly it will count. Some are very easy and inevitable, especially if you don't have to do a specific thing inside a single life. But some, like taking out multiple battleships on a single round can be pretty tough. But then there's the NUKE body part for that one. Hehe.

But anyway, still super fun for now.

reviewText:
An excellent-- and supremely difficult --game, chock with incredibly satisfying dogfighting goodness and the moments of over-the-top ridiculousness that we've come to expect from Vlambeer's titles.

The beauty of the game shines through when its brash bullet hell mayhem suspends itself for those few, brief moments where you are freefalling without a care in the world...  only to return and be ripped to shreds by incoming battleship fire.

100% recommendation.

You want this game.

Trust me.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
In short: this game isn't any '10-minute time killer' - it creates a sense of dedication in the player to improve. Worth every cent.

In LUFTRAUSERS, skill matters just as much as style. You are rewarded for playing well to the aircraft's strengths with large combos and/or survivability, but the game is not reluctant in the least to punish careless mistakes and exploit the plane's weaknesses from both above and below. The player is given plentiful options to craft their most favorable flight/combat experience, yet they must always be prepared to suffer the cons of their choices; frankly, the balances between Pro and Con in this game are commendable and always clearly stated.

The combat itself starts out quite simple with a few basic enemies to work with that are vulnerable to virtually any style. This acts as a sort of grace period for pilots testing new combinations. However, the game quickly works itself into a pilot's nightmare full of stray bullets, introducing new enemies in both sea and air. This steep difficulty curve, in combination with the mission system and various 'bosses', contributes greatly to the addictiveness of the game. New high scores give you a genuine sense of accomplishment and encourage the pilot to pursue other combinations that may help them reach even higher. All in all, LUFTRAUSERS is one tough survival test that will keep you coming back for more.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Luftrausers is an incredibly fun game which instantly throws you into the air to sink or swim. It's simple enough to grasp with minimal controls and easy to latch onto goal; if it moves, blow it up. It's a shooter, it's an action game, it's fun, and it'll have you hooked. If this doesn't make you want to be a Rauser pilot, I don't know what will.

Don't be fooled by the screenshots, this game is HARD. It appears easy, but it gets difficult fast. But unlike other games where ramped difficulty makes people want to give up after the first few tries, Luftrausers brings you back for more and more, giving you more options, more choices, more ways to kick some butt and blow stuff up. If you like a challenge, this game is definitely for you. You will spend hours with this.

What makes this game so delightfully addictive is it's simple elegance. It doesn't need to be decked out and fancy to be a really fun and difficult game. It's satisfying to achieve goals and relaxing if you want to kick back and blow off steam. The action is non-stop, the music is great, and the graphics are an awesome throw back to the days of Space Invaders. You become a part of this incredible world full of bullets and fire, and you will love every second of it. It's worth every cent, and for $9.99, you'd be crazy to pass up a game like this.

reviewText: Obligatory header to the review: I focus on four primary areas whenever I review a game: gameplay, story, graphics, and sound/audio/general things that go into your earholes. Gameplay and Story get a rating scale from 1 to 10, and the AV stuff gets a rating from 1 to 5. My philosophy on this is that there are some instances in which a game may not necessarily have that much in the way of gameplay (take Amnesia for example), but the story/atmosphere/whatever it may be is reason enough to pick it up. Also, take the cumulative score with a grain of salt; it's just a numerical feeling about the game as a whole. That's part of why I do these subscores. Also, keep in mind that I'm not going off of school grade based rankings. A 5/10 denotes what I feel to be an average game. Likewise, 7/10 is a game that I think is pretty cool, and something that gets a 2/10 is near-abomination level. Pinning scores to an even further obfuscated rating scale is kinda senseless, but for the sake of my backloggery, I'll repeat again that 1.0-2.7 is a one-star game, 3.0-4.7 is a two-star game, 5.0-6.7, 7.0-8.7, and 9.0-10 are three, four, and five stars, respectively.\n\nGameplay: Vlambeer has always been good at creating really simple yet excellently controlling games, and Luftrausers is certainly no exception. Essentially, you have four buttons: acceleration, boost left and right, and fire. You do have a health meter
date:
which is represented by a white circle closing in on you before you eventually die, which can be replenished by letting go of the fire button and not getting hit for a little bit. Speaking of death, this game is pretty tough. It certainly has that arcade style quarter munching level of difficulty. However, death is only a minor setback, as it only takes two to three seconds to get back into the action after dying. An average run won't last you much longer than two or three minutes, though.

Another aspect of this game is the customizable ship parts. You can get up to six guns, engines, and bodies, each with their own respective weaknesses and strengths. It is these parts, as well as the challenges associated with each and every part, that make Luftrausers much more than the simple arcade shooter I thought it was when I first saw it. There is actually a remarkable amount of depth for such a seemingly simple shooter (yes, that alliteration was intentional). My biggest complaint about the game - and it may seem minor, but it caused God knows how many deaths - is that every time you get hit, there is a frame or two of pausing. It stacks up whenever you're trying to manoeuvre your way through a hail of bullets. This is probably an intentional programming thing, as a ninety-some-megabyte game should not lag an i5-3470.

Other than that, I really don't have any big time complaints. Also, SFMT mode made me cry in the corner out of sheer terror. I haven't completed all of the missions yet, and I still haven't unlocked the [Classified] as of the time of writing this, but I've gotten far enough into the game that I feel that I am able to give it fair enough of a review. For only one big small" quibble

reviewText: Obligatory header to the review: I focus on four primary areas whenever I review a game: gameplay, story, graphics, and sound/audio/general things that go into your earholes. Gameplay and Story get a rating scale from 1 to 10, and the AV stuff gets a rating from 1 to 5. My philosophy on this is that there are some instances in which a game may not necessarily have that much in the way of gameplay (take Amnesia for example), but the story/atmosphere/whatever it may be is reason enough to pick it up. Also, take the cumulative score with a grain of salt; it's just a numerical feeling about the game as a whole. That's part of why I do these subscores. Also, keep in mind that I'm not going off of school grade based rankings. A 5/10 denotes what I feel to be an average game. Likewise, 7/10 is a game that I think is pretty cool, and something that gets a 2/10 is near-abomination level. Pinning scores to an even further obfuscated rating scale is kinda senseless, but for the sake of my backloggery, I'll repeat again that 1.0-2.7 is a one-star game, 3.0-4.7 is a two-star game, 5.0-6.7, 7.0-8.7, and 9.0-10 are three, four, and five stars, respectively.\n\nGameplay: Vlambeer has always been good at creating really simple yet excellently controlling games, and Luftrausers is certainly no exception. Essentially, you have four buttons: acceleration, boost left and right, and fire. You do have a health meter
date:
which is represented by a white circle closing in on you before you eventually die, which can be replenished by letting go of the fire button and not getting hit for a little bit. Speaking of death, this game is pretty tough. It certainly has that arcade style quarter munching level of difficulty. However, death is only a minor setback, as it only takes two to three seconds to get back into the action after dying. An average run won't last you much longer than two or three minutes, though.

Another aspect of this game is the customizable ship parts. You can get up to six guns, engines, and bodies, each with their own respective weaknesses and strengths. It is these parts, as well as the challenges associated with each and every part, that make Luftrausers much more than the simple arcade shooter I thought it was when I first saw it. There is actually a remarkable amount of depth for such a seemingly simple shooter (yes, that alliteration was intentional). My biggest complaint about the game - and it may seem minor, but it caused God knows how many deaths - is that every time you get hit, there is a frame or two of pausing. It stacks up whenever you're trying to manoeuvre your way through a hail of bullets. This is probably an intentional programming thing, as a ninety-some-megabyte game should not lag an i5-3470.

Other than that, I really don't have any big time complaints. Also, SFMT mode made me cry in the corner out of sheer terror. I haven't completed all of the missions yet, and I still haven't unlocked the [Classified] as of the time of writing this, but I've gotten far enough into the game that I feel that I am able to give it fair enough of a review. For only one big small" quibble

reviewText:
Do you enjoy danmaku (bullet-hell)? How about customisable aircraft? Or do you just want to have some fun?

If you answered yes to any one of those questions you'll probably love LUTRAUSERS.
Paying tribute to an era of arcade shmups it's one of the best gameplay focused games to come out in recent memory.

With hours worth of challenges, and loads of parts to unlock for your Luftrauser, it's well worth the $10. Above all else though, it's just plain, straight up fun. Wether you're dodging bullets flying at you from every corner of the screen, or plowing through enemies with your aircraft alone, you'll have tons of fun with this game.

reviewText:
Like most Vlambeer games, Luftrausers is fairly unconventional both graphically and mechanically. This is why I love it :P

You fly an ickle plane/jet from a side-scrolling perspective with 360 degree movement, mmmpf I love dat movement, against an eventual horde of enemies, ranging from gunboats and battleships to enemy Aces and giant blimps.

You unlock weapons, chassis', and engines each of which give you some distinct ability or trait. That's a *lot* of different combinations and therefore a lot of potential playstyles.

I'd buy this on Android if I could - its even better than Ridiculous Fishing :O



To summarise:

Pros: A brilliant Arcade shooter with tonnes of replayability and a butt-load of must-beat-that-score-yo.

Cons: Seems a bit too simple? I think it would be more at home on mobile devices etc if the controls were any good on dem touchscreens (I do like to touch things mind you).

Getting that high score can be a fairly random affair, even for the skilled.

reviewText:
The question you are all wondering; What does SFMT stand for?!?"

SFMT is a faster variant of Mersenne Twister (a pseudorandom number generator).
It stands for Single instruction
date:
multiple data-oriented Fast Mersenne Twister.

tl;dr
It basically spawns ♥♥♥♥ tonnes of enemies everywhere insanely fast."

reviewText: LUFTRAUSERS is a fantastic game. The dogfighting is absolutely brilliant, due to the stalling mechanic, and feels amazing. Doing a quintuple flip before turning on your engines and hitting the water makes you feel like a bada--. The combat is also awesome; the health mechanic makes you stop shooting for five freaking seconds if you want to survive, and poses quite the challenge. It seems a tad overwhelming at first, but you get used to it. You can also unlock loads of parts to alter your game play, and the random mode can be fun as heck.\nAll in all, LUFTRAUSERS is a good game. You should get it.

reviewText:
Another fun and addictive little game made by Vlambeer. Your goal in Luftrausers is to destroy as many planes, ships, submarines, even zeppelines and ofcourse try to dodge incoming bullets and fight gravity!

After you've beaten some of the objectives (like destroy 3 battleships..) you may earn different armor, engines and weapons. There are many different combinations and by trying them out you might figure out which is best suited for you.

Even though the game's graphics may look a bit 'simple' it does the job perfectly, also there's a great soundtrack and there are online leaderboards for you to test your skills vs other players.

Luftrausers is recommended to most arcade fans.

reviewText:
+Not using your thrusters is just as important as using it. You get significantly more turn control when your engine is stalled, allowing precision aiming and redirecting your movement in ways that defy realistic physics in favor of exciting gameplay.
+The health system is interwoven into the weapons system. Pausing your onslaught lets you recover your health pool. The game plays alerts and puts an iris-in on the player when health is at dangerous levels.
+Working together, there's an interesting and frantic dynamic of healing, attacking, moving, and steering that I've not seen any other game pull off.
+Your planes, the 'Rausers', are customizable with the parts available. Mix and match for 126 different combinations that suit your style. Each of them even has their own name.
+Soundtrack is dynamic. Each different Rauser part introduces a different melody, percussion, or bass-line to the song that is constructed for your session.
+Camera is pretty solid at keeping itself oriented around what the player wants to be looking at based on where their Rauser is pointed and their current velocity.
*Artstyle is minimalist, but minimalist is perfect for this type of game as it keeps visual noise on the down low so it can bombard your eyeballs with waves of bullets and enemy planes.
-Scoring and combo system is heavily conflicting with the random enemy spawns. High-scores are incredibly dependent on a particularly rare enemy unit to spawn and then subsequently dispatched with a x20 multiplier.

Overall, it's an incredibly well-tuned and fast-paced experience that is immensely satisfying to pick up and play for a few rounds, just don't go in expecting to be plugging hours away doing score attack as the numbers are ultimately meaningless beyond a certain point.

reviewText:
Luftrausers is a frenetic aerial combat bullet hell 2D retro dogfight shooter or whatever you want to call it.
Basically you have a simple 4 button control scheme of turn left/right, boost forward, and shoot.
As you play you unlock more ship parts to customize with. Mix and match parts in sets of 3 with guns, hulls, and engines. Each part has a few achievements that you unlock in succession when you use those parts. Also they affect the soundtrack variation in a way I have yet to figure out.

reviewText:
Luftrausers is a frenetic aerial combat bullet hell 2D retro dogfight shooter or whatever you want to call it.
Basically you have a simple 4 button control scheme of turn left/right, boost forward, and shoot.
As you play you unlock more ship parts to customize with. Mix and match parts in sets of 3 with guns, hulls, and engines. Each part has a few achievements that you unlock in succession when you use those parts. Also they affect the soundtrack variation in a way I have yet to figure out.

Take to the skies and set ablaze all who dare stand in your path using your ultimate aircraft and you divebomb into boats to explode them.

reviewText:
This is just purely an extensive arcade 2D shoot 'em up.

The main goal of the game is to survive long as possible and and try to score  maximum possible points.
The longer you are in the game, the more enemies coming at you.
And try at all times to keep your combo at 20x for a long time to get a crazy high score.
That is most the arcade part of the game is you ask me.

Beside that you have the option to customize your plane with a few upgrade you unlock along the way.
Every parts gives you some new mission to play ... and give you a new goal and will keep you playing.
Some mission are very hard to get if you ask me.

I find this game super challenge and very addictive to a certain point of the game.
Overall I think it's a great game and will give you some playing time.
Replay value is good and this can be better if you ask me.

I give it a 7/10 score.

reviewText:
Recommended: If you at all liked classic arcade side-scrolling shooters of old, LUFTRAUSERS is right up your alley.  It's a well-made side-scroller with high production values and excellent execution.

LUFTRAUSERS is a classic side-scrolling arcade shooter made by Vlambeer and published by Devolver Digital.  Vlambeer is a game development house that has a certain knack for having their game ideas ripped off by mobile developers, and there's very much a reason for that: they make simple, arcade retro games very, very well, with an imitable art style and direction.

At it's heart, LUFTRAUSERS is a side-scrolling shooter set in a sort of alternate reality at the birth of jet flight, full of all kinds of anachronistic references to old science fiction and a rich graphics style that fully realises and embellishes the genre.  The art style in general is very well-implemented, as is the sound design.  It all fits together very well.  The music design deserves special mention, because the in-game music changes slightly depending upon your choice of hull, weapon, and engine.  So very different choices of plane will result in very different in-game music and it is a way of adding variety to the game that hasn't been much used before.

The game mechanics are simple, but work very well.  The divergence from simple normal side-scrolling is the inclusion of a stall mechanic - when you are engaging the engine boost, you simply glide, which allows greater precision in turns at the price of losing altitude and slower forward momentum.  It allows for a high skill ceiling in the maneuvering and some truly amazing stunts.  Coupled with a variety of weapons, hulls, and engines that all act differently, the game not only offers a variety that keeps the game fresh, but also allows a player plenty of latitude to find a combination that fits their play-style.  The controls are responsive, and it plays just fine with a keyboard, though this is another game that definitely feels more authentic with a classic controller.

The enemies in the game are varied and become incrementally more difficult as you survive longer.  It starts as simple fighter planes, but progresses to patrol boats, jet fighters, ace pilots, battleships, and more.  On top of that, unlock enough and you can unlock a SFMT Mode" that not only greatly increases the speed at which the enemy progression occurs
date: but also unlocks new enemies to fight
recommended: as well as affords new unlocks for yourself.\n\nAll in all while the game mechanics themselves are fairly simplistic
hoursPlayed: there is plenty of variety to keep you engaged and the production values for this kind of game are as high as one might have come to expect from Vlambeer.  if you like side-scrolling shooters
voteText: then I think you'll find a lot to love in LUFTRAUSERS.\n\nPublished: http://highlandarrow.com/index.php/reviews/86-review-luftrausers"

reviewText:
My first time playing this game I was swearing with the vocabulary of a well educated sailor. I kept dying and had no idea WTF I was doing. Eventually I got the gist of the controls and experimented. After that I was hooked.

With only 4 keys (Left, Right, Boost and Fire) you'd think it'd be easy. Just pop in, hold Up/Boost, fly around and shoot things... and you'd be wrong. The controls may seem simple, but it's one of those games where that simplicity leads to a whole load of complexity when it comes to mastering this game. You have to get used to the idea of letting your plane freefall now and again, boosting at the right time and dodging bullets. Get enough enemies on screen (and off) and the game begins to remind me of Japanese Bullet Hell shooters, there is that much going on, and it's trying to kill you.

As you gain higher and higher scores and complete challenges, you level up, unlocking new parts for you plane, letting you customize it (doing so even changes the planes name). And each part has a series of challenges attached to it, so what challenges you have change depending on which parts your using.

Seriously, for $10 this is a ♥♥♥♥ing amazing game and one well worth looking into even if you don't like air combat games, because this is very, very far from what you'd get in something like Jane's.

reviewText: LUFTRAUSERS is a fast paced indie shoot em up, with a focus on movement and customisation, giving ful 360 degree freedom of movement and a wide open space to move around in, and 125 combinations of weapons, chassis, and thrusters. These affect things like attack type, health, abilities (such as ramming or going underwater). Each part also has several challenges, which are used to unlock new parts and secrets in the game (such as colour palettes). There are a wide range of enemies, ranging from small fighter planes, to massive blimps which rain bullet from the sky (while battleships and submarines do the same from the sea). The action is fast paced and there is little time between death and starting a new run, keeping the flow of the game.\n\nLUFTRAUSERS is a fun, addicting shoot em up, which adds a new take on the genre, whilst keeping with a lot of the conventions. The visuals are interesting and unique, and the music does make you feel quite awesome, especially as it changes based on the parts you are currently using. Overall, a great game for when you feel like blowing stuff up in style.

reviewText: LUFTRAUSERS is a fun, challenging little game with suprisingly good replay value, given that the game essentially consists of a single stage with endless waves of enemies. LUFTRAUSERS is the most basic of arcade shmups in that you play until you die and hope to get a high score. However, it has more depth then most games of that type thanks to a range of interchangable parts that greatly effect your Rauser's performance in combat. You may choose from weapons, fusilages and engines, each with very different behaviors. Each of the many, many combinations has its own name and there is an achivement for trying them all once, by far the most time-consuming one. You can also change the game's color palette away from its default, deliberaitely monochromatic sepia tones, though most of these alternate schemes will wear on your eyes. The music also changes to match each configuration of your Rauser, and the game comes with the seperate audio tracks to create your own remixes. While thin for its list price of $10, the game is well designed, with responsive controls that challenge you rather then hamstring you, and an overall stylish presentation. Well worth getting on sale.

reviewText: After about an hour of playtime, you will have seen enough to know what to expect from this game. That is not a bad thing in this instance because Luftrausers  is a great arcade experience that relies heavily on gameplay and control. Not much of a campaign or story to speak of, but the dogfighting feels sublime. reviewText:
This game is another shining diamond from Devolver Digital, makers of one of my all-time game series Hotline Miami.  (It even features some recycled Hotline Miami musik, so you know that part is wonderful.)

A triumph for pixel art in games.

Works off the principle that what goes up must come down (YES!--gravity), using this physic to create a whole new twist to twin-stick shooter arcade play.  Also, playing like a suicide-bomber can be to your advantage as you can use your plane to melee enemies as well as to fire missles.  Very challenging gameplay (the achievements will most likely not be hard to cook through, but the game itself provides a beautiful challenge and you can compete for high scores).

The art is simplistic, but subdued, easy on the eyes, and beautiful.  The art style is unique and fun, the kind of art you would expect from Devolver.  Beige color-scheme is interesting.  Play-style is customizable (you can alter weapons/parts of the ship).

The gravity mechanic doesn't make sense in light of the German war Aero-plane theme, but oh well.  It's a video game  and absurdity is welcome.  The sky and water serve as a function of the game, not just backdrop, so I guess it all works.

I came to love this game in a very short time and this is definitely doing to be one of my top picks for a long while.

reviewText:
A very addicting arcade shooter with insane acrobatic maneuvershttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gt0dfOKVgwk
+ Nice background music that fits very well with the game
+ Unique very addictiong mechanics
(you can spin and change direction to dodge bullets while gravity is constantly pulling you down, however you must stop shooting for your health to regenerate, so it's a mix of dodging while trying to find time to shoot)
+ A variety of different weapons, engines, and body parts that create a different experience each time
+ Challenges (which you need to complete to unlock more parts) are similar to achievements, and make you play differently each time depending on the challenge. (like kill 5 boats)
+ The Airship boss is pretty awesome and takes some time to figure out how to defeat it.

- There's no health bar, so it can be hard to tell when you are about to die. Basically a circle appears around your plane when you are close to death.
- The Difficulty can feel a bit unfair at times, it's randomly generated so some playthroughs are easier than others.
- There's really only 1 level in the game, so I feel like it's lacking content / repetitive
- The Screen-Space is quite limited making it hard to see where enemies are

reviewText:
LUFTRAUSERS is a game about “superweapon dogfighting in a world with World War II-era Thunderbirds”. It takes place somewhere between the Second World War and the Cold War, or in an alternative reality in the ten to fifteen years after the Second World War. We’re talking the age of fear for mind control, floating sky fortresses, orbital rays, weaponised dolphins, cryptography and submerging warplanes. The player is part of an undefined enemy force that was not on ‘our’ side during the six or seven decades in which military intelligence was effectively telling us to prepare for a laser-equipped hoverboat assault. It's pretty awesome.

As a Vlambeer game, LUFTRAUSERS has a lot going for it. The game is all about big bullets, lots of screen-shaking explosions, fun mechanics, and ridiculous controls. Like with all Vlambeer games, it features a high skill ceiling and difficulty while maintaining easy accessibility and addictive gameplay. Aesthetically, it has simple but great pixel art and vibrant color palettes. KOZILEK's soundtrack is amazing; it subtly changes as you customize your Rauser with different guns, hulls, and engines. Everything about it just feels amazing.

There are a few flaws, however. The user interface is a little clunky; I've had trouble remapping the controls and the menus are a little hard to navigate. Players might get turned off by the simplicity and lack of content as well as the difficult missions. Still, I definitely think it's worth the $10. It's one of the best air-combat/dogfighting games I've ever played.

TL; DR: for fans of fun games.

reviewText: BEWARE. This game does not allow you to change the volume settings or any options until after you beat the tutorial stage. This is important enough to be the first line of this review because if you're like me and like to chat with friends over voicechat, you may need your master volume turned up pretty high and adjust games as needed. I almost didn't even play this game because of how loud it was on startup and there was nothing I could do in-game to fix it. Eventually after some googling I took some time away from friends to mute everything so I could pass the tutorial and actual fix the in game volume.\n\nNow, after that this is an extremely fun game. The arcade action is quick and fun and there's a ton of different configurations of parts to make your Rauser out of. Well, if a ton is equal to One Hundred and Twenty Five. Still, there's a lot of variety and each part has it's own mission objectives, giving some direction other than just scoring and adding to longevity to the experience. The four color aesthetic works wonderfully and the music plays to the action very well. Besides the red and sepia look there are other color schemes to unlock, most of which I've found are completely terrible, but they are completely optional and don't take away from the core experience which is so fun that the only real complaint I have with it is that I wish there was more!

reviewText: LUFTRAUSERS is a fun, challenging little game with suprisingly good replay value, given that the game essentially consists of a single stage with endless waves of enemies. LUFTRAUSERS is the most basic of arcade shmups in that you play until you die and hope to get a high score. However, it has more depth then most games of that type thanks to a range of interchangable parts that greatly effect your Rauser's performance in combat. You may choose from weapons, fusilages and engines, each with very different behaviors. Each of the many, many combinations has its own name and there is an achivement for trying them all once, by far the most time-consuming one. You can also change the game's color palette away from its default, deliberaitely monochromatic sepia tones, though most of these alternate schemes will wear on your eyes. The music also changes to match each configuration of your Rauser, and the game comes with the seperate audio tracks to create your own remixes. While thin for its list price of $10, the game is well designed, with responsive controls that challenge you rather then hamstring you, and an overall stylish presentation. Well worth getting on sale.

reviewText: I've poured about 24 hours of playtime into Luftrausers and I can finally say that the game is very barebones. Sure, the floaty controls and 2D shooting is satisfying, for a few hours that is. There's only 15 parts to customize your aircraft with, 7 enemies to dogfight with, and 1 gamemode: shoot things to get points until you die. It's an endless wave game with some very frustrating elements to it such as the simple art style which is pretty, but can interfere when there's a bunch of similarly colored things on the screen and compounded by immense screen shaking when things explode and stuttering when you take damage. The 100 challenging missions" the game touts is nothing more than a list of basic and boring goals such as "Kill a Blimp" or "Get a score of 8000" that is effectively a list of achievements that quickly becomes a test of luck down the line with its pseudo-difficulty.\n\nThe bullet hell nature of the game is also hindered by the fact the camera is heavily focused on your rauser despite all the airspace available
date: you will often find yourself flying straight into a cloud of bullets that leaves you a very small window of opportunity to dodge whereas other bullet hell games gives you view of the entire field to plan out your maneuvers. All of this and the game asks you for $10
hoursPlayed: but for that price one could buy other replayable games with truckloads of more content such as Binding of Isaac

reviewText:
Look, this is basically a Flash game, like the kind you'd play for free, packaged as an application.

However, Luftrausers is $10, it features an abysmally-balanced set of weapons and add-ons that are just full of bad ideas and poorly-designed features.

Gameplay-wise, it's vaguely borrowing from Defender, Asteroids and most of all, Wings Of Fury (which if you haven't played, do it NOW or get the FREE clone of it, Wings Of Fury 2, which isn't bad).  It's a physics-based game, kind of, except when it's not.

My biggest critique is that you don't make progress; you unlock a bunch of stuff that looks cool, but mainly isn't.

Stuff like body that's a blade that makes you weaker than default but doesn't insta-kill hard baddies on impact hits so net the heavy armor does more DPS + survivability".  Basic stuff.  Stuff that should have been addressed

reviewText: Let me start by asking you a question: have you played War Thunder? Yes? Good game, that. This is nothing like it.\nFor a start, you will usually have a better K/D, and generally, if you intentionally crash into an enemy then you will probably be flying a nuclear bomb. That way, it's more satisfying when you die. Basically, there are 15 different interchangable parts, in 3 categories, giving 126 (don't ask about the last one) possible planes. To unlock them is easy, you just need to play mediocre for a while. However, each part has several missions, such as kill a submarine on max combo (I'LL GET YOU ONE DAY YOU LITTLE ****ER), which, when completed, get you a little further towards unlocking Plane 126. Expect to be pummeled and to pummel in your quest for the illusive final Rauser, and never drop dat combo.

reviewText: Okay... this game... is awesome! it's amazingly (addictively) fun to pilot a plane like this. the mechanic of your plane being repaired whenever you don't shoot is ingenious, adding a bit of risk vs. reward to every second of play. each new part adds to the experience, and whenever I got frustrated, I found myself switching out a part or two to create a completely different play style, and the pallette swaps are a nice touch.\n\nHowever, there are a few gripes I have with the game. Several enemies can take you out in a snap, sometimes when they're not even on screen. I've had several occasions where I've gotten out of an intense dogfight with only a scrap of health left (with little else on the screen) only for a jet to zoom in and smack into me. Battleships either need less health or shoot less bullets, and an ace can often times take you out before you have any time to react. For several hours, most of my objectives consisted of take out a blimp to continue"
date: but I can't for the life of me tell you the spawn conditions for one (sometimes they appeared 30 seconds in
recommended: sometimes three minutes of intense fighting will pass with niether hide nor hair). Blimps don't spawn nearly often enough to develop a strategy
hoursPlayed: and when I finally did beat one it was by dying with the kamikaze bomb part.\n\nDespite it's shortcomings

reviewText:
This is one of those lovely game that tries it's best to not be extremely difficult just for the sake of it, but sadly, is. Between the extremely low health and damage that any Rauser combo produces (in comparison to what you are up against) you still get overwhelmed easily.

The game goes from slow to bat-♥♥♥♥-crazy in a matter of 30-45 seconds. The combo counter resets far too quickly and is impossible to keep if the game decides to stop spawning the little weak planes. Battleships often spawn on top of eachother and create a hail of bullets that even the high armor body can't eat. The randomization makes it far too luck based.

Overall, this game makes a real solid effort and I am sure many people are up to the challenge. This game is for them. I however will take a pass on the drag-your ♥♥♥-across-razorblades" difficulty in hopes they tweak and balance the game a bit more. Maybe introduce a planes only or boats only mode

reviewText:
Fast paced plane shooting game and yeah it's roguelike.
Your main objective is to finish all the missions & gain scores to max your level.

You're not only fighting a plane, you also fight boats.
There are many types of enemies you have to fight with.
The difficulties went higher overtime so it's hard to survive longer.

Each time you finish a missions or level up you gain new parts for your plane.
Each part has different attributes and you can match them up to create a new plane types.
There are 125 types of planes that you can pilot.

There is also SFMT mode which is insane difficulty mode that make this game more challenging.
If you're up for the challenge then grab this game.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Amazing game; don't buy it.

It really pains me to have to say this, but LUFTRAUSERS, one of my favorite arcade games, is broken. I've tried reinstalling it approximately fourteen times now (because it used to be just that good), but me, along with a massive chunk of gamers on the community hub, just can't get it to open.

Even my friends, who I recommended this game to immediately after playing it, can't even get it to work, so I couldn't possibly recommend it to you, lest you become one of the dozens of people online, on forums, or even looking for help on this games page, that can't get it to even work at all.

A damn shame too, because this game used to be amazing. One of the best pick up and go games with an unparalleled soundtrack. Now I'm just curious if it's too late to get my money back.

reviewText:
A really fun little indie title from one of the most proficient indie studios out there.

Luftrausers is a remake of an old flash game called Luftrauser (originally not Vlambeers game). The remake has enough new and fun content that will keep you consumed for the next week or so.

The greatest part about Luftrausers is without a doubt the combat. With the added gravity added to each airplane you'll feel like there's real weight in your Rauser when you're gliding through the air while shooting down a swarm of enemies. Added to this there's also a bullet hell feel to it where you dodge bullets and missiles while trying to get that extra score multiplier.

The game also has a dynamic soundtrack that changes with what parts you use with your Rauser. The changing music keeps the game fresh even though you've heard a similar track several times before.

The only negative that I can think of is that some parts (weapons/armors/engines) are a bit unbalanced and needs more work. It would also be nice if it was possible to crack down on the cheaters whom riddle the leader boards.

I'd personally highly recommend this game for all bullet hell, indie and arcade fans out there. The game is hard, but also so rewarding when you get the hang of it.

reviewText: While it has its moments, it doesn't have enough to provide me entertainment beyond just a few minutes. Its biggest issue is the pure lack of content, or rather the rate at which you unlock new airplane parts. Maybe 20-40 minutes into the game I unlocked every single plane part (except for the top secret last ones), and thus I really had nothing else to play for. While there is that final unlock, it just becomes a technical challenge and a grind due to the lack of unlockables, which makes for painfully unfulfilling gameplay.\nOverall I would give this game a 4.5 out of 10, because it gets very old very quickly.

reviewText:
+Easy to learn, hard to master.
+Fun, natural, and interesting movement.
+Good challenges and progression system.
+Parts are unique and combining them is fun.
+Great music.

-Enemies could use more variety.
-Most of the color filters aren't very nice.

reviewText:
I don't normally get into shmups, but this one is a lot of fun. The asteroids-style control scheme adds to the experience and the simple color palette lends a style that I find interesting.

Playing the game you will unlock new parts for your plane and new graphical color palettes that can be changed out. This adds some variety to the gameplay or allows you to somewhat tailor the game to your playstyle.

The only negative thing I have to say about the game would be that it seems to be capped at 30 FPS. It definitely doesn't feel like it is running at 60 FPS, which I think would be a much better experience for this type of game. Hopefully this is something that can eventually be addressed by the developer.

reviewText: This game, is quite honestly, the most fun game I have ever played. With the quick unlocks of new kinds of aircraft parts, the different gameplay styles that come with them, and the great dynamic soundtrack make this game a fun, epic, and unique game. In addition to lovely music, each new aircraft part can add new abilities, such as exploding on death, being able to fly underwater, etc. The flying controls are also excellent! You can turn on/off the thrusters and rotate freely however you want, allowing for the many parts of your plane to show off how they work best. For example, if you have a spread gun, heavy frame, and a superbooster, you would lead a ton of enemies in one direction, then cut the thrusters and fire backwards. On the other hand, if you had the melee frame, laser weapon, and underwater booster, you would keep low, spear through ships, and take down planes with the laser. The possibilities in this game are endless and so is the fun! I would recommend this game to anyone, no matter who you are.

reviewText:
So, I'm just a few parts combinations away from full completion of this game, and wow. Just... wow.

You start off in a pretty simple manner; you have a standard machine gun, normal armour, and an engine. Letting go of up stalls the engine, allowing you to begin drifting back to the water. Entering the clouds or the water causes you damage, to start with anyway. Stop firing, and any damage you took begins to regenerate. And that's the nice, simple start.

By the end... Well, you'll be flying around furiously, firing giant fireballs that explode on impact with an enemy, equipped with a submarine propeller so water no longer hurts you, with the fuselage of a nuke that explodes on your death. Oh, and there'll be a siren going off, and not long after it's likely you'll be dead.

And eventually, after some seriously difficult challenges... you'll unlock the U-Rauser, and boy, you probably didn't see that coming. But you'll have enjoyed every second.

reviewText: This is a frenetic, side-scrolling dog fighting game and it's a lot of fun!  The fact that it's a side-scroller means that simply allowing your plane to fall is a valid movement strategy.  You have unlimited ammo and your health will regenerate but you can only use one at a time.  Your health doesn't regenerate while you're shooting so you really need to balance your approach to attack and defense.

I am the skies.

And I... I... am become death indeed...

reviewText: The most difficult game I have ever played. By far. Because it has the worst controls I have ever seen in a game in my life. No matter what, it is impossible to get used to the controls. I can't fly at all because the controls are so nightmarish. I don't care what anyone says, the controls are the worst in the history of video games. It gives me almost no real control over my plane. All I could do was fight gravity to stay out of the water but I just kept dipping down into the water. I can really only kill planes by unavoidably slamming into them. You have to stop firing to repair your plane but you still can't because the screen is filled every milimeter with bullets and planes that are impossible to avoid because you have no proper control over your plane. How this game got past their quality control team blows my mind. Obviously they have no QA department. Hopefully this gets taken down from the steam store and at least there's Hotline Hiami, which is pretty much the only great game that Devolver has made.\n\n0/10 horrible

reviewText:
LUFTRAUSERS (yes, it's actually allcaps) is an arcade-esque bullet hell shooter in which you are a RAUSER, aka, a plane 'ace', as it were. As a RAUSER pilot, it is your job to protect the Fatherland with glorious engineering bestowed by... blowing up ♥♥♥♥.

LUFTRAUSERS has fun, addictive gameplay, and retraux graphics that somehow manage to be more detailed than a lot of other games relying on the same art style. Sparks fly from your plane, smoke billows from damaged enemies, and explosions shake the screen like you've had too much coffee. The overall feel of playing is seriously engaging, as every shot you take and every movement you make feels... just fantastic. For every major accomplishment (such as, say, blowing up your first battleship) you get a short little cutscene celebrating your accomplishment, making you feel genuinely proud of your amazing skill.

Upgrades are unlocked fairly frequently, but the real challenge is unlocking the final three mystery parts. Trust me, that ♥♥♥♥ is worth it, and don't spoil it for yourself.

For those of you who truly find joy in pain, there's also an unlockable SFMT mode, in which the game takes it up to 11... and breaks the scale. Good luck surviving that.

In short, LUFTRAUSERS is a seriously engaging, pew-pew explosions, defend our engineering and take down hordes of enemies with this plane, simulator. Worth it at base price, must-buy on sale.

reviewText: LUFTRAUSERS is pretty much what it looks like: an arcade dogfighter. I was expecting a story mode or something similar, but all I got was a straightforward 2D shoot-em-up. That having been said, I am not in the least disappointed by what I received; this game knows what it does and does it well. It provides the classic arcade experience of scoring as much as possible without dying, throwing in for bonus the rush of excitement when you stall in midair, watching hordes of enemies and waves of bullets streak past you in a whirlwind of death. The stalling mechanic is really what makes this game so good; you can stop accelerating and simply let gravity do the work of dodging hazards for you, then after changing direction speed up at the last second and escape the jaws of death. Obviously it's not a lot of content, despite the number of ship parts allowing for a commendable combination of ships and thus playstyles. For what I paid, however, I'd say I easily got my money's worth.

LUFTRAUSERS is a game that offers a great challenge that looks and sounds great, too, and is a stellar title (but with a couple notable exceptions). [. . .]

reviewText:
Cool idea, but not worth $10.

This is nothing more than any general flash game, and runs about as well, if you're lucky.

What promises to be a fun arcade shooter with customization is a bunch of options that are not particularly useful or good against everything, which leads you into positions of not being able to do anything, making the entire affair rather boring, overall.

The sense of health is tried to be made intuitive through visuals but does not seem consistent in representation, some hits taking off 2 to 3 times as much than they do at other times.

Good idea, but not much execution.

reviewText:
LUFTRAUSERS, a game as whole as it's own trailer entails it to be, not much more but perhaps less then one would expect from a 10 dollar game on steam. I have not played the Flash version of this game, but after playing, what is in my opinion, an overpriced flash game. Here are a few reasons why:

Controls:
It is easy to tell from a mile this game was made for a gamepad, as none of the menu screens have mouse control, and more often than not end up taking you where you did not want to go in the first place. An example would be trying to costimize the Rauser, getting to the Hanger is as easy as pressing right with the arrow keys or D-pad, but instinctively would immidiately start trying to optimize the desired prefrence for the craft. Instead have to confirm what you want to customize the plane, a simple rotation selection screen, then have to press X to set the plane as complete. Key-binding is awful, a set track of trying to understand what you want to bind to makes for a frustrating adventure, where a simple sheet simply saying what key is for what button would have made this game worlds better. On top of ths, it appears I cannot find the file that contains the text file to easily bind what I want to which key.

In game flying feels unnatural as well. reviewText:
Luftrausers is a game where you engage fighter planes over sea. Made by Devolver Digital and Vlambeer, it has a delicious arcade feel to it, meaning it can be played for 5 mins or 5 hrs, depending on the mood you may be in. Multiple enemy types to destroy, many leaving the player with a great feeling of satisfaction (I'm looking at you, battleships and blimps).

There are lots of different parts available to the player for the customization of their rauser. There are also many unlockable color palettes to choose from, which allow you to change up the flavor of your rausing here and there. The difficulty is perfectly scaling, increasing a little more with each kill, each passing second of your continued survival. The one big drawback I've found with this game is no multiplayer option. Even a local VS mode would help add so much more variety to this already immensly addicting game.

If you like techo/electro music with a sort of diesel influence, you will love the soundtrack of Luftrausers. It has a great selection of tracks which perfectly match up to the setting of your aireal combat. If you are looking for a mobile-esque timesink, look no further than LUFTRAUSERS!

9/10 needs moar firepower

reviewText:
Extremely fun.  While I can see some fighting the controls a bit at first, it doesn't take any time to become comfortable with the  game.  While never totally easy, the game does start out at a very comfortable pace, but the action and difficulty can ramp up very quickly.  There are a few various parts to choose from when it comes to plane customization, but not an incredible amount.  This game is less about having a ton of options and things to do, it's focused and fun.

Menu controls are different with how you navigate the games various menus, but again it nothing that isn't quick to adjust to.

I had one problem when I first got the game, I believe it didn't launch right or something like, which was easily fixed by disabling the Steam overlay.  But that was quite a while ago so the issue may be fixed.  But that's it in terms of issues.

Overall it's an extremely fun and challenging game, that is way more addictive then it has any right to be.

10/10

reviewText:
Gameplay: Luftrausers is an arcade-style shoot 'em up based around completing objectives (e.g., score 5000 points, kill a battleship at max combo). Your aircraft's weapon, body, and engine are customizable, which encourages development of different tactics. Enemy spawn inconsistency adds variety to gameplay, but leaves certain objective completions largely in the hands of chance. Given the short life of a typical game (a few minutes), this randomness is tolerable, but I wish they would have toned it down. A high level of skill is nonetheless required, but you might have to burn though several dozen attempts before enemies spawn conducive to your current objectives.

Controls: Compact and elegant: left, right, accelerate, fire. Body/engine build choices yield different maneuverability, all of which feel beautifully responsive (some more than others for intentional balance reasons). Controls are the highlight of Luftrausers, and fans of arcade classics will love it for its feel.

Presentation: Its simple graphics are immediately readable, and aircraft-specific musical adjustments make me feel like an angel of death. Menu navigation feels a bit clumsy. My biggest presentation gripe is during the hardcore" SFMT mode
date: where you are continuously exposed to a blaring air raid siren. The only in-game way to eliminate that overwhelming sound is to disable sound effects
recommended: which are crucial to high-level gameplay. The appealing minimalist aesthetic is offset by flaws which could have been easily addressed."

reviewText: Picked it up in the sale, and i can definitely see this game becoming my go to pick up and play for a few minutes game until i find another game like that. Its fun to just go in and play a few rounds. Sometimes the round you just had  felt really good so you'll play another and that happens. The music is good i hope they release the soundtrack soon. This game has a really good feeling slingshot flying mechanic. There is delay with your control in flight so you have to take that into account when dealing with enemies. Your ship can also take a decent amount of shots before dying and all you need to do to heal up is fly around without shooting. Definitely recommend, I bought it for $5 but if i'd known how much I'd have enjoyed the game I'd have probably bought it at full price.\n\nAlso you have to alt+tab out to leave the game and then right click and exit. So thats like a built in minigame puzzle that they put in for free
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
At the time they were making Luftrausers, Vlambeer was dealing with the soul crushing experience of their previous game being cloned in the iOS marketplace.  Luftrausers is their expression of a personal hell, for our entertainment!

An endless cycle of death, gunfire and explosions against a enemy that will never, ever die.  Only respawn in greater numbers.  The most effective weapon is a nuclear explosion that will take your enemies with you.  A dank soundtrack that sounds like a march to war, evolving as you play, but keeping the same plodding theme.

After playing this game with headphones on a few nights ago, I achieved that wonderful state of videogameness where I could not leave the screen, putting all 3 settings on random and falling into such a groove with the constanly changing soundtrack that I found myself humming it all day afterward.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Maybe I'm not on the same page as everyone with this game, but I feel like it's a borderline frustration game.

The customization makes the gameplay very different each time you equip different items. This gives the game a lot more play time, and diversity, since the combinations of items makes you basically start from scratch to learn how to control your plane.

You need to work very hard to feel satisfaction in this game. It takes a bit to get used maneuvering your plane, and even when you do the feeling of being shot down after a mere 2 minutes can be enough to make someone take a sledgehammer to their controller.

For those who love an Asteroid-style Shmup and an intense challenge, get this game. For me though, the frustration of trying to progress gives me a similar feeling that I got while playing Flappy Birds.

reviewText:
From when I first turned it on, I was unable to stop playing this great game for nearly 5 hours. The feedback loop of just one more round along with no waiting time between attempts just kept me hooked. It has a great soundtrack, one which works amazingly when your ship is in critical condition while the heroic refrain of the track blazes high as you thread the needle through a sea of bullets and coming out the other side! The core gameplay mechanic is a joy to play with.

There are some issues, notably it does not make it obvious how to quit (you can quit on the screen with the carrier). Along the same lines is that its menus could had done better. Some of the mission design (for unlocking new parts and giving you goals to work for) could had been better. Some of the parts could be better balanced.

The game does seem perhaps a little too hard. Mostly in that I shake my fists at those pesky battleships, especially when more than one start stacking together to make a cloud of death. Yet as hard as the game is, you can eventually lock a mode which turns the game into a literal bullet hell.

But on the whole, it was very enjoyable and a great surprise. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
A lot of people say that this game is a pile of crap and that it's too hard or too short or too repeatative. Most of them would be right; It's too hard, too short and too repeatative, but it's definitely not crap in my opinion. What evolved from a flash game had come a long way into being what it is today. I've played many bullet hells in my youth, from Striker 1942 to Project Raiden to Sylpheed and even the unknown gem that is Einhander. Most of these games however are just lightweights to the REAL bullet hells that are out there hoever; you know, the kind that have and entire screen lit up with bullets that can only be dodged by a simple tap of the joy-stick as you just BARELY make it through alive? Yeah those make this game look like a chump, but never the less, this is in fact a bullethell game.

It's a hard game to play, but the controls are simple to master. Once you understand the controls and have a better understanding of the momentum/physics mechanic of this game, the rest is left up to ou and your own skill. This game starts off simple enough, but eventually gets harder and hard with each enemy you destroy. You'll pit off against standard planes, PT boats, Jets, Battleships, Aces, missle launching submarines and even enormous blimps that act as floating combat stations. I found the game quite enjoyable, well when I wasn't trying to unlock new weapons by completeing acheivements for each peice of equipment I had on my plane. However even though I found the game quite fun, it has it's small flaws.

The game only has on song, but the song changes depending on what chasis, weapon and engine you equip. After a while of progress eventually the enemies will start to swarm you, making it almost impossible to maneuvar as enemies seem to focus more on ramming into you with no self preservation and filling up the air with a seemingly endless barrage of bullets. Some acheivements are almost impossible to complete unless the stars are aligned just right and the gods of chaos decide that it is time for you to complete your calling. Finally, once you destroy a blimp, the supposed boss" of this game
date: the enemy will begin to throw everything at you INCLUDING the kitchen sink and then some
recommended: which is where you'll realize that this is pretty much when the game's decided "ok it's over
hoursPlayed: you can die now."\n\nEven with these flaws though
voteText: the gameplay feels so good and satisfying
helpfulPercent: and the music is pretty catchy
votesHelpful: even though it's starting to lose its touch. It's a guilty pleasure that I love to play and I would recommend that people play it at least once."

reviewText:
This game is just pure fun. It's very simple - all you do is fly around and shoot things - but it's the way it feels that makes it so much fun to play and almost impossible to put down. It has that one-more-round phenomenon going on.

It's kind of a game that has to be experienced to fully get why it's so great, but watching some videos should give you a good impression. The planes are incredibly responsive and every weapon is super fun to use. There's a ton of unlockable plane parts too, which all make huge changes to how you might choose to approach the game. This, together with the different Achievement style missions attached to each part, gives the game a hell of a replay value.

Visuals and music are also amazing. The minimalistic look makes it easy to see what's going on even when there's a million planes and bullets on the screen. The music is amazing and it changes dynamically (based on your plane I think?) so you'll never get tired of it.

You might only end up playing Luftrausers for a few hours but they'll be some amazing hours.

reviewText:
Alright, before we get going, I'll say right off the bat this game is not worth $10.  I might even go so far as to say it's not worth $5.  It's definitely a game you should only buy on special.

Now, with that out of the way, let me start with the highlights of the game.

The graphics and music are excellent, I love the artstyle in general, it's very quirky and has a lot of personality.  The game is quite difficult but simple to play.  Easy to pick up but hard to master certainly applies here, especially if you're going for points.

Now, for the bad bits. Just a forewarning, this negative impression might be coloured by my own level of skill as opposed to the game itself, but either way, here's my two cents.

Though the slightly random generation of the levels does help, it doesn't feel like there's quite enough enemy variety, at least not as far as I've seen. Perhaps there's much more if you survive for a lot longer than I have but I'm a bit skeptical.

The game also focuses on combo chaining to get points but after you clear the initial wave of little planes that chase you, and if you're good enough to clear out the boats, all you're left with to kill are huge battleships, large aircraft that move much faster than you do and have a large chunk of HP, and massive airships (if you're lucky enough to have them spawn at all).  All of these enemies have too much HP for your weapons (which don't increase in power throughout your run) to take down with any efficiency, and the 5 second timer for your combo meter is not nearly generous enough for you to get more than a couple multipliers before it resets at this point.  There are still the cruise missiles and the fighter jets that streak around but the cruise missiles don't seem to appear in enough quantity and the fighter jets are too fast to reliably shoot down to keep up your combo meter.

Also, speaking of the points, due to the flaws that I perceive in the score system, it is difficult to get much more than 10,000 points in a successful run, which makes unlocking new parts a bit of a grind since it can take tens of thousands of points to unlock a single new part for your plane later on.

The final nail in the coffin for me is also the fact that, despite the interesting range of part combinations that you can put together in this game to create your own unique vehicle, I ended up feeling that the only combination that really worked to survive and score with any efficiency was pretty much laser + high HP body + fast engine.  The HP difference between the high HP body and everything else rendered almost all the other bodies moot, especially when you pair the high HP body with the high speed engine.  It doesn't help that all of these parts are quite literally the first set of parts you unlock.

Clearly some of this is subjective in how you approach the game, how good of a player you are, and which body combination works for you (though it's hard to imagine how any of the other bodies could surpass the massive HP difference of the high HP body), but I feel the scoring system, weapon unlock system, and the unviability of the various part combinations makes this a frustrating experience that quickly becomes repetitive.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Graphics: 2/3
Story: 1/3
Game Play: 3/3
Re-playable: 1/1
Sale Rate: 20%

Total: 7/10

Graphics: 2/3
The game has a clean Indy style focusing on brown scale tones with large bullets so you can easily see and sometimes dodge them. Your own plane looks different enough that it doesn’t get lost in the fighting without it looking foolish and too cartoony. Everything sticks nicely to the games aesthetic and it looks like an old arcade machine.

The music has a marching drive to it, spurring you on. There is a weird choice to make the music track restart on launch so if you die in the first few seconds you hear a sharp stop and start of the soundtrack.

Story: 1/3
As far as I can tell, you are a German flying the most advance plane in the war. The evil Churchill has declared total war against the Glorious Third Reich and only you can stop his relentless assault over the British Channel. You fight not for glory or for riches, you fight for the survival of your glorious empire.

I don’t know if this was made by Germans or someone simply said, “you know what we have too much of? The Allies' side of the war. Let’s change that”. It wasn’t until I killed Churchill in his war zeppelin that I realized I was playing as a German.

Since this is a score attack rogue-like game, it doesn’t need a story or dialog to keep you playing. It does create a uniform world with some discovery, but no great mystery. Doesn’t add or subtract anything.

Game Play: 3/3
This game gives some great visuals to assist your gameplay. There is no health bar or ammo, thereis only the dog fight. There is no power ups or health drops, there is only the dog fight. There are no allies, there is only the dog fight.

When you take damage, the screen starts to get narrower. To regen health, you just stop shooting. Enemies play by the same rules as you, when you crash you lose health, but you might kill the enemy. To accomplish this your plane can maintain speed after you stop thrusting. So you can fly across the screen while shooting backwards.

The controls are tight and the feedback is instant. There is a large number of supported play styles with different planes geared directly for. At a certain point you get a randomizer to add a new element to the game.

Re-Playability: 1/1
You unlock new parts after you die, and there is one plane body that turns you into a nuke on death.

Should you buy it?
I had more fun playing this with friends than alone. Has some good value, but nothing world changing, buy on a lite sale.
Note: single player only, you need friends in room.

reviewText:
I would absolutely recommend this game if it was working properly.

When it was functioning it was a great, fast paced, shootemup with an interesting graphical style that was very pleasing to the eye while being very simple. The challenges presented for each module of your aircraft produce a feeling that makes you want to keep playing. Unlocking new parts and guns for the planes reaches its peak rather quickly, if you play well, so having teh challenges present for each module is a nice touch.

Thats all the good i will say...

The game worked great on my work pc, which was the first pc i installed it on. However when i tried to install the game on my gaming rig later that day, the game would not even get past the opening screen without one of about a million different variations of glitches would take over, making it impossible for me to even start flying a plane.

I tried every fix i could find online and contacted the developers through the message boards. I got one reply initially that led me nowhere and then the devs seemed to just give up and abandon the message boards entirely. After not getting any replies to my numerous posts and questions for over 4 months i gave up on that idea. Tried to contact them by email. No luck. Back to fixes. you guessed it, no luck whatsoever.

Now i am stuck with a game that will only run on my work computer, that i can scarcely play only when i am on break or waiting around after work for a colleague. The worst part is I ACTUALLY ENJOY THE GAME!

I just wish the devs would have helped me and plenty others in fixing the major issues with the game. It really bothers me that i hear thorugh the boards they are already working on their next game (so now my hopes for fixing 'Luftrausers' is really crushed) and have been through some tough times" so try to understand.
I paid $10 for an indie title

reviewText:
Remember those halcyon days, back in the '90's?
You're ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed parents have dragged you someplace boring (The Mall, Bowling Alley, Outlet center, ETC), but...What is this? An arcade?
You cry, beg, steal, & threaten till you recieve the adequate amount of spare change or converted greenbacks for this elysian corner of an otherwise tartarian adult environment. It doesn't matter how many times you die, or (for those with siblings like me) whose turn it is, it's a glorious distraction.
Luftrausers is that feeling.
It doesn't matter that the graphics are minimal.
It doesn't matter that the story line is nigh nonexistant.
It's an arcade game, and you have UNLIMITED QUARTERS.
So sit down, grab a soda, and forget that you're (XX) years of age.
AND %$#*ING SHOOT SOME PLANES DOWN WHILE YOUR AT IT.

reviewText:
Luftrausers is a game with amazing mechanics that is sadly marred by some borderline unreasonable objectives later into the game.

The main draw of Luftrausers is the beautifully responsive flight mechanics that you get to play with. By cutting your engine, you are able to 'stall' in the air, allowing you to shoot in any direction as your craft is carried on by momentum and gravity. I cannot dexcribe how awesome it feels to arc over a battleship as you sweep your lasers across its hull, or blow a tailing enemy squadron out of the sky with a well timed cannon shot as you fall backwards towards the ocean.

And yes, you do have multiple weapons options for your 'rauser' (plane). There are a number of customisation options for the guns, hull and engine, which are unlocked by some algorithm tied into mission completion (see next paragraph). Though these seemingly offer different playstyles, and add something to the progession model of the game, I found that a significant number of 'upgrades' were rendered (sometimes immediately) obsolete by clearly better alternatives. For example, the nuke body will perform a screen-wipe upon your death, but these kills aren't added to your score. So apart from helping with a small number of 'kill [X]' missions, this body is outright inferior to the body that just buffs your health.

Though the game is designed to be like an old-school arcade game where the main objective is maximising score, for each customisation option, there is a short string of sub-objectives. This allows you to attempt up to three missions per round, with one tied to each part of your ship. These start out simple enough, but by the end of the game, they start to veer into RNG-fests that require you to kill high-profile enemies at maximum combo. (Kill an enemy to increase combo by 1, maxes at 20; standard combo fare.) But this requires you to get a max combo, sustain a max combo, and do the three-plus attack runs required to kill the target, all in one round. If that target never spawns (submarines, you scumbags!), then tough luck. I found myself quitting out of frustration after a while, because of the increasingly unreasonable missions.

Having made those complains, I am still reccomending this game. Why? Because 'I cannot dexcribe how awesome it feels to arc over a battleship as you sweep your lasers across its hull'. I don't know how much life you'll get out of this game (it depends on your levels of perseverance), but it's cheap and the core mechanics are just that good.
